question: What were the derivations of the terms diabetes mellitus and diabetes insipidus?
a_text:
The name diabetes comes from the Latin diabētēs, which in turn comes from Ancient Greek διαβήτης (diabētēs). The name refers to its major symptom — polyuria (frequent urination). The literal meaning of the word is “a passer through; a siphon”.
The name is first used for a disease causing an “excessive discharge of urine” by the 2nd century Greek physician, Aretaeus of Cappadocia, but the symptom itself was recorded by a 3rd Dynasty by physician Hesy-Ra.
The word “diabetes” is first recorded in English, in the form "diabete", in a medical text written around 1425. It was commonly referred to as “the pissing evil” during the Middle Ages.
Mellitus comes from the Latin word for honey and refers to the “sweetness” of the urine, due to glycosuria (excretion of glucose into urine). Up through the 11th Century, diabetes was commonly diagnosed by “water tasters”, who would drink the urine of those suspected of having diabetes and describe its characteristics, including whether it tasted sweet.
Insipidus comes from the Latin insipidus, meaning tasteless. This is because diabetes insipidus does not exhibit glycosuria.

question: What is the best way of controlling the dawn effect in type 2 diabetes?
a_text:
Here’s a recommendation from Dr. Castro of Mayo Clinic.
The dawn phenomenon, also called the dawn effect, is the term used to describe an abnormal early-morning increase in blood sugar (glucose) — usually between 2 a.m. and 8 a.m. — in people with diabetes.
Some researchers believe the natural overnight release of the so-called counter-regulatory hormones — including growth hormone, cortisol, glucagon and epinephrine — increases insulin resistance, causing blood sugar to rise. High morning blood sugar may also be caused by insufficient insulin the night before, insufficient anti-diabetic medication dosages or carbohydrate snack consumption at bedtime.
If you have persistently elevated blood sugar in the morning, checking your blood sugar once during the night — around 2 a.m. or 3 a.m. — for several nights in a row will help you and your doctor determine if you have the dawn phenomenon or if there's another reason for an elevated morning blood sugar reading.
What you can do
Your doctor may recommend a number of options to help you prevent or correct high blood sugar levels in the morning:
Avoid carbohydrates at bedtime.
Adjust your dose of medication or insulin.
Switch to a different medication.
Change the time when you take your medication or insulin from dinnertime to bedtime.
Use an insulin pump to administer extra insulin during early-morning hours.

question: What changes did you notice in your eyesight when your diabetes progressed?
a_text:
That’s a REALLY great question! I was diagnosed with Type II in Feb. of 2016. At first, I was terrified that I’d be a HORRIBLE diabetic! I like sweets to much and was already quite over weight… (still am, but I’m doing better about it.) So about three days after being diagnosed, I was sitting on the toilet and had ALL the terrible thoughts going through my head of the possible complications of uncontrolled diabetes. My grandmother was always referred to as a VERY brittle diabetic, which I now understand wasn’t about how bad her diabetes was, but was instead about how little effort she put towards controlling it… Her diet was horrible! So anyway, I’m sitting there with all these thoughts rolling through my head. Suddenly, I hit blindness. It was about the equivalent of hearing tires screeching on pavement trying to avoid an accident… and then the horrible gut wrenching sound of metal crunching. The thought of going blind crossed my mind. Not just going blind, but what that really meant, in a practical everyday kind of way. Not just having to walk with a cane or a seeing eye dog, not really even unable to read a book anymore, to see a Spring blossom, no. I had the unescapable thought of what it would be like to have to humble myself to the degree that I had to ask someone to come and look at my toilet paper to assure that I’d wiped my butt clean after a bowel movement! In that instant collision of potential reality and understanding of who could best control that out come, I decided instantly that I could in fact, be a GREAT diabetic! Simply by watching my diet (carbs mostly) I brought my A1C down from 10.8% to 6.1% in 3 months. Then, in 2017, I had a short lapse of stupidity and stopped paying attention sufficiently, (my daughter introduced me to a new sweet pickle on the market and I went CRAZY eating pickle and cheese sandwiches!) I gained 20 lbs in one month. I literally went through, I think, 9 jars of pickles that month. But it might have been 12… I know right? DUH! My vision got kind of blurry one day, so I checked my blood sugar. It was almost 500! I went to the ED and got treated and was put on glipizide and actos. Fortunately, the pickles weren’t overly well received and they quit carrying them. On one hand, I was kind of bummed, but on the other hand, it made it SO much easier! But it took several weeks for my vision to completely clear back up. It was bad enough that I was a little bit concerned about driving. Not because I couldn’t see the other cars well enough, but because I was having trouble reading the road signs until I got right up on them. Fortunately, I was only driving in familiar territory, otherwise, I wouldn’t have felt it safe to drive. Even now, I question whether it really was even then…
I think that diabetic complications are probably different for each of us and you just have to get to know your body and how it responds to things. We checked my A1C again about 3 weeks ago now. I was still on the glipizide, but had already been taken off the actos. The A1C came back at 4.9%. My doctor says he wishes he could farm me out to all his diabetic patients! I laughed at him and told him probably not… I don’t always behave. I might not always be the poster child he had envisioned… Anyway, about two weeks ago I had to touch base with him because twice in one week I had my sugars dropped to the low to mid 40’s. I think one was 43 and the other was 46. He immediately took me off the glipizide. So, now I’m back to being totally diet controlled. Oh,… what I failed to mention was that the coming off of meds and the low A1C was due to the fact that I lost 15 lbs this summer. Just by walking. I have lung disease and am on high flow oxygen. Exercising is very difficult for me. But I moved into a new LARGE apartment building and have no choice BUT to walk… I take the dog out twice a day… That’s ALL it’s taken. But it’s made a sufficient amount of difference that I’m just about to the point now that I could choose to just go walk up and down the hall the length of the building to increase my exercise. I could do it indoors and have the climate control that I need and can’t get when outdoors. I think that if you’re having trouble with weight, one of the most important things to remember is that you didn’t gain it quickly and you won’t lose it quickly. Just stay the course, watch what you eat, both in content and proportion. Diet changes should not be a diet, but a lifestyle change that you can adopt for keeps.
I know that this was kind of long and convoluted, for which I apologize, but if it can help anyone, it was certainly worth the time to me to type it out!

question: What is a diabetic coma, and what causes it to occur?
a_text:
The answer by Fosuza Mensah contains many inaccuracies…
Diabetic coma is ALWAYS due to a deficiency of insulin and part of the syndrome is ALWAYS an elevated blood sugar!
This is in COMPLETE CONTRADISTINCTION to hypoglycaemic coma that is due to too much insulin, either in absolute terms or in relation to having not eaten enough…
The only similarity is that they are both potential complications of diabetes…
The treatment of these two conditions is completely different and so is the clinical presentation…
Diabetic coma can be subdivided into two categories:
Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a complication of Type I Diabetes mellitus; and
Hyperosmolar non-ketotic coma (HONK) is a complication of Type II Diabetes mellitus.
Both syndromes are, as already noted, due to a deficiency of insulin. However, for DKA to occur requires a pretty absolute deficiency of insulin because the cardinal biochemical marker of DKA is dramatically elevated ketone bodies. These ketone bodies are derivatives of free fatty acids usually stored in peripheral fatty tissue in the form of triglycerides. An enzyme found in this fatty tissue is hormone-dependent lipase. This enzyme’s activity is usually completely suppressed by insulin and it takes essentially absent insulin levels to allow this enzyme to become active. Once this enzyme is allowed to become active then substantial amounts of triglycerides are liberated by the hydrolysis of triglycerides found in the peripheral fatty tissue. These triglycerides will circulate in the blood and are then taken up by the liver to produce ketone bodies. These ketone bodies can then be used by tissues instead of glucose as an energy source that are insulin-dependent and hence cannot use glucose as an energy substrate.
In DKA the reason for coma is not a lack of energy substrate. The CNS is not insulin-dependent tissue anyhow and so can access glucose in the absence of insulin. Instead, the metabolic holocaust induced by the lack of insulin causes a substantial metabolic acidosis (predominantly due to ketone bodies, but in severe cases also by a lactic acidosis), severe hyperkalaemia, hypomagnesaemia (often only unmasked once treatment is begun) that is a consequence of the polyuria that is induced by the hyperglycaemia, and dehydration, also a consequence of the polyuria and nausea and vomiting due to the ketoacidosis that, in addition to increasing fluid loss, also inhibits oral intake. All these together cause the coma that is characteristic of DKA. The whole syndrome usually takes hours to days to develop and often experienced diabetics (to their credit) recognize the problem and present early to hospital and so prevent a full-blown life-threatening event. The most common precipitants of DKA in Diabetics are, otherwise trivial, illnesses like a cold or influenza, or a self-limiting infectious gastroenteritis. Without treatment DKA is universally fatal! With treatment mortality is low but still finite!
The coma in HONK shares some similarities with DKA but there are also substantial differences as well…
In Type II Diabetics the insulin deficiency is almost never extreme enough to allow the activation of hormone-sensitive lipase. Thus ketoacidosis is rarely a feature of HONK. However, the insulin deficiency is enough to precipitate a severe hyperglycaemia (levels are often much higher than one sees with DKA). The reason for this is that the syndrome develops at a slower rate than with DKA and so glucose levels in the blood have more time to rise. Dehydration is also often much more of a feature for the same reason. The dehydration is commonly severe enough to induce a shocked state and this, in turn, usually precipitates a severe lactic acidosis due to generalized tissue hypoperfusion. Electrolyte abnormalities induced by the lactic acidosis and prolonged period of polyuria are often more severe than those encountered in DKA… The overall metabolic chaos and its consequences in HONK result in a higher mortality than DKA in those who are treated appropriately. Untreated HONK is also universally fatal.
The coma in HONK is also due to the extreme dehydration and shock, as well as the severe electrolyte and acid-base abnormalities observed. The syndrome typically takes longer and develops slower than is the case with DKA. The mortality associated with HONK is often exacerbated by overzealous medical management where overdoing fluid replacement early and trying to normalize the blood sugar too quickly result in a cerebral oedema that can be fatal. (This is also a potential problem in children presenting with a DKA.)

question: How does type 2 diabetes really affect the brain?

The Scary Way Diabetes Affects Thinking Skills And Brain Function. ... These changes are linked with an impaired ability to regulate blood flow in the brain, due in part to inflammation, which is a common component of Type 2 diabetes. Normally, the brain distributes blood as needed to areas of increased neural activity.
A growing body of research is finding that diabetes can take as devastating a toll on the brain as it takes on the body.
A new study published this week in the journal Neurology
shows that people with Type 2 diabetes demonstrate a decline in cognitive skills and ability to perform daily activities over the course of only two years.
These changes are linked with an impaired ability to regulate blood flow in the brain, due in part to inflammation, which is a common component
of Type 2 diabetes.
Normally, the brain distributes blood as needed to areas of increased neural activity. In diabetic individuals, however, this process becomes impaired.
“We have shown that people with diabetes have abnormal blood flow regulation in the brain, namely impaired ability to increase blood flow and deliver sugar and oxygen to the brain during episodes of increased mental activity,” the study’s lead author, Dr. Vera Novak of the Harvard Medical School, told The Huffington Post in an email. “Inflammation further alters blood flow regulation in diabetic people and contributes to mental and functional decline.”
For the study, the researchers recruited 65 men and women with an average age of 66, half of whom had Type 2 diabetes and half of whom did not. The participants were given a series of memory and cognition tests at the outset of the study and again two years later. They also received brain scans to measure brain volume and blood flow and blood tests to measure inflammation and blood sugar control.
Here are some of the key findings:
· After two years, the people with diabetes showed greater declines in gray matter as well as impairments in their ability to regulate blood flow in the brain than the people without.
Blood flow regulation decreased by an average of 65 percent in the participants with diabetes.
· Among participants with diabetes, scores on thinking and memory tests decreased by an average of 12 percent, from 46 to 41 points, while test scores of the participants without diabetes stayed the same at 55 percent.
· Higher levels of inflammation were correlated with greater difficulties with blood flow regulation.
· Those with the highest levels of blood flow regulation impairment at the outset of the study had more difficulties performing daily activities (such as cooking and bathing) after two years.
The study is the latest to observe a link between diabetes and cognitive decline. With a growing body of research showing an association between insulin resistance and neurodegeneration, some scientists are even referring to Alzheimer’s Disease as “Type 3 diabetes.”
Hopefully, these findings will one day be used to devise better treatments for the degeneration of thinking and memory skills co-occurring with diabetes. A new trial by Novak’s team is currently underway to determine whether injecting insulin into the brain might slow cognitive decline.
But for now, better detection and monitoring of blood flow regulation could help predict and manage cognitive challenges in people with diabetes.
“Worse performance on daily activities, worse memory or slower gait speed in older diabetic adults may hallmark a decline in ability to regulate blood flow in the brain,” Novak told HuffPost. “For older diabetic people it is important to maintain healthy lifestyle and minimize fluctuations of blood sugar levels, in addition to their medication regimen.” (Extracted from Huff. question: If diabetes is declared a disease, would that affect how hard an individual fights diabetes?
a_text:
Q: “If diabetes is declared a disease, would that affect how hard an individual fights diabetes?”
What on earth makes you think diabetes is NOT a disease? There are two major categories of diabetes, and within those two, there are FOUR and THREE utterly different diseases. ALL of them are taken seriously as diseases by any competent healthcare provider. Let’s review.
DI is very rare; DI is Diabetes Insipidus. It has four types; they are all related to an issue with the use, storage or production of the hormone vasopressin - aka, anti-diuretic hormone. This hormone regulates fluid-balance in the body. In these patients, there is polydipsia (excessive thirst), and polyurea (excessive urination). The excessive urine is insipid - colourless, odourless and tasteless.
DM is the disease most people are talking about when they refer to “diabetes”. DM is Diabetes Mellitus; “diabetes” means siphon (relating to the symptoms of excessive thirst and urination), while “mellitus” means “honey-sweet”, referring to the symptom of dark, sweet urine. All three types of DM involve an issue with either a lack of, or poor response to, the hormone insulin - the primary BG (Blood Glucose) lowering hormone (there are several more hormones involved in BG control).
How seriously a patient takes a diagnosis of DM is PURELY the individual’s choice… ALL types of DM are deadly, and can cause some HORRIBLE “complications” long before death frees us from the disease. I know of NO healthcare provider that does not consider these diseases seriously. But many patients, in denial at time of diagnosis, do. To their own detriment.
I’ve been a T1 (Type 1 DM patient) for over 53 years - since I was 11 years old. I have ALWAYS taken it seriously, and have always “fought” to control my BG levels - which is the key to living a long, healthy life with any type of DM. T1 REQUIRES daily multiple injections of insulin (or a constant infusion drip of insulin) to stay alive - because our bodies make NONE, and without insulin - we DIE. That may make it easier to accept the seriousness of the disease - for many T2s, the initial symptoms may be mild enough to ignore; but for us T1s, they’re not.
But ultimately - it’s the PATIENT that must accept the fact they have a disease that REQUIRES treatment - regardless of how pronounced that treatment is - in order to live a long, healthy life with the disease.
BUT… many of us CAN, and DO.

Abdul Muntakeem Piash asked: Why are diabetes patients increasing rapidly in the world?
My answer: Abdul, I am assuming you are asking about type 2 diabetes mellitus. T2DM is a metabolic disorder marked by increasing resistance of insulin receptors to accept insulin effectively blocking fuel (glucose) into the cells. In the USA at least you can add a couple of ethnic groups that are more susceptible to T2DM, native peoples and those of sub Saharan African descent.

I suspect that the reason certain population groups are more prone to developing metabolic disorders is because they have evolved in environments where periodic famine is part of a the ordinary cycle of life. question: What precaution should a diabetic patient take?
a_text:
Diabetes prevention: 5 tips for taking control
Changing your lifestyle could be a big step toward diabetes prevention — and it's never too late to start. Consider these tips.
Images: Google images.
By Mayo Clinic Staff
When it comes to type 2 diabetes — the most common type of diabetes — prevention is very important. It's especially important to make diabetes prevention a priority if you're at increased risk of diabetes, such as if you're overweight or you have a family history of the disease or you have been diagnosed with prediabetes (also known as impaired fasting glucose).
Mayo Clinic does not endorse companies or products. Advertising revenue supports our not-for-profit mission.
Diabetes prevention is as basic as eating more healthfully, becoming more physically active and losing a few extra pounds. It's never too late to start. Making a few simple changes in your lifestyle now may help you avoid the serious health complications of diabetes in the future, such as nerve, kidney and heart damage. Consider these diabetes prevention tips from the American Diabetes Association.
1. Get more physical activity
There are many benefits to regular physical activity. Exercise can help you:
Lose weight
Lower your blood sugar
Boost your sensitivity to insulin — which helps keep your blood sugar within a normal range
Research shows that aerobic exercise and resistance training can help control diabetes. The greatest benefit comes from a fitness program that includes both.
2. Get plenty of fiber
Fiber may help you:
Reduce your risk of diabetes by improving your blood sugar control
Lower your risk of heart disease
Promote weight loss by helping you feel full
Foods high in fiber include fruits, vegetables, beans, whole grains and nuts.
3. Go for whole grains
It's not clear why, but whole grains may reduce your risk of diabetes and help maintain blood sugar levels. Try to make at least half your grains whole grains.
Many foods made from whole grains come ready to eat, including various breads, pasta products and cereals. Look for the word "whole" on the package and among the first few items in the ingredient list.
4. Lose extra weight
If you're overweight, diabetes prevention may hinge on weight loss. Every pound you lose can improve your health, and you may be surprised by how much. Participants in one large study who lost a modest amount of weight — around 7 percent of initial body weight — and exercised regularly reduced the risk of developing diabetes by almost 60 percent.
5. Skip fad diets and just make healthier choices
Low-carb diets, the glycemic index diet or other fad diets may help you lose weight at first. But their effectiveness at preventing diabetes and their long-term effects aren't known. And by excluding or strictly limiting a particular food group, you may be giving up essential nutrients and often craving such foods. Instead, make variety and portion control part of your healthy-eating plan.
When to see your doctor
The American Diabetes Association recommends blood glucose screening if:
You're age 45 or older
You're an overweight adult of any age, with one or more additional risk factors for diabetes, such as a family history of diabetes, a personal history of prediabetes or an inactive lifestyle
After age 45, your doctor will likely recommend screening every three years.
Share your concerns about diabetes prevention with your doctor. He or she will appreciate your efforts to prevent diabetes and may offer additional suggestions based on your medical history or other factors.

question: Why is there no permanent cure for diabetes? Why was no major breakthrough achieved after inventing insulin hundred years ago?
a_text:
I am going to assume that you are asking about type 1 diabetes.
Insulin wasn’t invented one hundred years ago. Insulin is the glucose-regulating hormone that exists in almost every animal. In fact, a lobster has insulin that is only slightly different than human insulin. In the 1920s, we were able to isolate insulin from pigs and it was used to start regulating blood sugars in type 1 diabetics. However, there was a lot of allergies to the insulin, so scientists spent a lot of time trying to isolate the genes that produced human insulin.
In the 1980s, genetic engineering companies were able to mass produce human insulin, which was a major breakthrough, more important than isolating pig insulin 60 years earlier.
Throughout the past 40 years or so, the genetically engineered insulin has been greatly refined to include fast, medium, and slow acting versions which are better at regulating glucose levels. We have insulin pumps that release insulin close to how the pancreas would do it. These are also major breakthroughs.
Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease, which are very difficult to understand. In this case, the immune system attacks the insulin-producing cells of the pancreas, destroying the ability to produce insulin. We don’t know what the etiology of type 1 diabetes is, but we know it has a genetic component with some sort of environmental trigger, probably a serious viral infection. Once we understand the cause, we may be able to stop it or reverse the damage caused, and maybe cure type 1 diabetes. Some researchers are looking at ways to turn off the autoimmune response, and once that happens, it appears that insulin production returns. But it is only been shown in animal models, and early clinical trials have begun with some interesting results.
I’m guessing within 10 years we’ll have another major breakthrough.
But you are wrong to suggest that the last breakthrough was 100 years ago. Science doesn’t have many eureka movements — it progresses as data and new hypotheses are tested. There’s not going to be a miracle moment where someone yells, “we’ve cure diabetes.” Each additional step allows scientists to move closer to a potential cure. I studied insulin and diabetes in grad school, it was a part of my thesis. That was 40 years ago. What I know now, makes my dissertation seem like it was written by cavemen. Seriously, we didn’t know it was an autoimmune disease 40 years ago. We didn’t know the genetics of diabetes. You think that a cure is the end point, but you need to build a foundation of scientific knowledge to get to a cure. It’s evolutionary not revolutionary.

question: What does diabetes do to legs that result in amputation?
a_text:
I will avoid dragging you into the weeds of physiology and biochemistry. I am writing for a high-school education level layperson.
Route one: Infection
An uncontrolled diabetic suffers damage to the nerves over time; this is called neuropathy. It can result in pins-and-needles feelings, pain, numbness, and other symptoms. The areas affected classically get called the glove-and-stocking distribution by physicians way older than I. Basically, a diabetic’s nerves in the hands and feet are malfunctioning. Such individuals have poor sensation in their feet and often do not feel injuries properly.
Second, uncontrolled diabetes damages blood vessels and usually occurs with comorbidities that further damage blood vessels. This has two effects. First, the person has poor wound healing due to a mix of poor blood supply to the distant parts of the limbs and other metabolic derangements, and second, they have poor transport of immune cells to the distant parts of the limbs. Again, this is usually compounded by the patient’s comorbidities; most of our diabetics have other health conditions that decrease their circulation. Poor circulation also makes it so antibiotic concentrations in any wounds are lower than we might hope for, and antibiotics have to be tailored to the diabetic patient’s other comorbidities (liver and kidney disease often being limiting factors).
Next, dysregulations due to diabetes cause immune dysfunctions aside from the poor circulation. Essentially, an uncontrolled diabetic has a less efficient immune system and is more susceptible to any pathogens that invade.
Finally, many diabetics are not taking the best care of themselves for various reasons. Often they show up only when things are in a crisis, especially when poverty is a factor. Never underestimate the social determinants of health!
So what happens: In a typical case, our diabetic suffered a small wound to the foot or lower extremity that they didn’t really notice because their nerves are borked (not a technical term). Bacteria invaded and started a fairly typical cellulitis. Due to their decreased sensation, they didn’t really notice. Due to their poor wound healing and poor immune response and poor circulation, the bacteria spread and managed to get to bone or cause enough tissue destruction that it got ugly with resulting infection of the bone (osteomyelitis) or gangrene. Initial antibiotic therapy was less effective due to poor circulation. Due to poverty or other social conditions, the patient didn’t seek out help until the situation was critical and it was lose the foot or lose your life.
Route two: Peripheral vascular disease
Diabetes, on its own, is a risk factor for damage to the blood vessels and high cholesterol, which can cause damage to arteries. Diabetics, due to choices, age, and social determinants, often have other comorbidities that cause them to have poor circulation and higher risk for the arteries of the extremities to become too damaged to sustain the limb. In this case, diabetes is contributory to all the other health issues damaging circulation to the limb until the limb just isn’t going to make it.
So what happens: Imagine a patient of 78 years with a two-pack-a-day smoking habit, overweight, high cholesterol, no exercise, diabetic. After a stroke, our patient doesn’t walk anymore. The circulation in our patient’s legs is very, very poor. Eventually, it is so bad that the leg below the knee is non-viable and amputation is the only real option.
Route three: Other Causes (Trauma, Surgery, Cancer, etc)
Diabetes reduces your survivability and ability to heal from any trauma that befalls you. Simply put, our diabetic is not as resilient as a non-diabetic due to those circulatory and immune factors discussed above. When recovering from a devastating illness or injury, they will be far more likely to have a bad outcome. Likewise, if they need surgical care (for example, after an accident) they are far more likely to have dangerous surgical complications. Likewise, if the surgical team tries to save a limb, you can bet a non-diabetic has better odds all other things being equal.

question: What organ system functions are affected by type 2 diabetes?
a_text:
“What organ system functions are affected by type 2 diabetes?”
All of them. Really.
Type 2 diabetes mellitus is caused by cellular resistance to the action of insulin. Insulin’s “job” is to facilitate the transfer of glucose (the fuel EVERY CELL OF THE BODY runs on) from the bloodstream (the body’s “delivery system”) into all of the cells. Every cell of the body has “insulin receptors” on it… and these receptors “recognise” the presence of insulin, and “open” the cell wall so that glucose (a large, crystalline structure) can pass through, and get inside the cell - where it’s “burned” to make ATP (Adenosine TriPhosphate) - energy.
In T2 (Type 2 diabetes mellitus), ALL of the cells have impaired insulin response. This is aka “insulin resistance”. The underlying cause is GENETIC… but the biochemical cause is this “resistance”. In short - the genetic issue is a flaw in the genetic code that codes for insulin receptors in the cells and their function.
When that function is faulty - the cells don’t get the fuel they need as fast as they need it… but at the same time; too much glucose builds up in the bloodstream. And this causes damage to EVERY CELL OF THE BODY.
To start - glucose is a crystalline structure; imagine running sandy water through a garden hose; that’s what’s happening in ALL of your blood vessels. You’re abraiding the insides of you blood vessels, gradually “wearing them down” from within. AND… you’re also generating a deadly excess of AGES - Advanced Glycation End productS.
AGES are created in excessive quantities when too much glucose is present in the blood. Glycation is a chemical process wherein the protein of your haemoglobin binds with portions of the sugar molecules in your blood. This is a normal process, and in non-Ds (non-Diabetics), anywhere from 3.5% to 5.5% of their haemoglobin is glycated. BUT… when BG (Blood Glucose) levels are higher than normal (about 90 to 120 mg/dl all day long, with 80% of the day spent BELOW 100 mg/dl), more-than-normal amounts of glycation take place, and too many AGES are created - and left “floating around” in your bloodstream.
AGES are a sort of “sticky-sweet gunk” that attaches to, smothers and kills off the cells of the tissue in your vasculature - and ultimately, EVERY organ of your body that your blood comes into contact with - in other words, EVERY CELL of your body.
Here’s a useful article which, while focused on cardiovascular issues, outlines it well: Advanced glycation end products and vascular inflammation: implications for accelerated atherosclerosis in diabetes
Ultimately, elevated BG levels cause ALL of the associated “complications”, or “co-morbidities” of diabetes mellitus - of the Type 2, Type 1, and Type 3c varieties. Here’s a link to the most pervasive studies of BG levels and “complications” ever done - though it was done in Type 1 diabetics, it’s applicable to ANYONE suffering from elevated BG levels: Blood Glucose Control Studies for Type 1 Diabetes: DCCT and EDIC | NIDDK

question: How can hypoglycemia be more dangerous than diabetes?
a_text:
Hypoglycemia is not a straight-forward condition that exists or presents 24/7. It comes and goes in most people.
Most of the time it is better called Intermittent Hypoglycemia.
What is critical in particular is driver education. The police say blood sugar issues are a matter for the medical community because it’s a medical condition. The medical community (when you can even get a medical person to comment) says it’s road safety condition and not their bailey-wick. So we have a Mexican stand off on one of the most easily fixed, deadly serious, very common, health and safety issues known to man and no one wants any part of it.
There are reasons for that.
Police themselves are prime offenders although not as bad in Canada as they used to be. When a fatal accident occurs involving a hypoglycemic person, that person’s blood is not checked unless asked for by the coroner. The problem is that as the involved hypoglycemic becomes aware just before impact, the impending disaster changes the blood sugar instantly and distorts the reading.
That is okay with the police, especially when it’s one of their own.
There are significant reasons for that:
When you have an accident while you are having a hypoglycemic incident, you are impaired.
Since you are impaired, your insurance is null and void immediately.
You get charged with impaired driving if you live.
If you’re a cop and you die, not only is your insurance null and void, your widow’s pension is lost as well.
The cruiser is usually a write-off and also uninsured
The contents of the cruiser’s computer can be lost especially if there’s an electrical malfunction that fries the electrical system or there’s a fire.
The officer’s case load is lost.
The investment to develop the officer is also lost.
An accident of this nature can easily cost a police department a couple of million for a single vehicle accident where no one else was involved. As soon as others are involved the costs have no upper limit. Taxpayers are on the hook for the whole thing.
The most common offenders though are transport truck and long haul heavy equipment drivers.
Those people typically have zero nutritional knowledge and drive for years with Intermittent Hypoglycemia. They get away with it until they don’t.
When they don’t they generally kill and maim other people. So each of these accidents are devastating due to the scale of the event and the potential for involving other people, structures, the road bed a and sometimes the local environment. These accidents cost millions. That is an expensive outcome for a coffee and a doughnut.
Now apply what the various physicians have said are the risks to the person affected. As important as they may be on a personal scale, the broader picture can beggar the imagination.
Yet the police and medical authorities throughout North America at least all absolve themselves of the responsibility for taking the initiative to educate the driving public.
I have been trying to get this subject into the public domain since I wrote a short story for a contest in the Toronto Star in 1998. It didn’t win. Try to imagine how many lives have been lost since because I didn’t win that contest.
That’s not to say if I had won anything would have been done. But having won, I’d have had a launch pad to work from. I’m still looking for that launch pad.

question: Do you have any pro tips for an individual who's been told they're likely developing diabetes (type still undetermined)?
a_text:
Q: “Do you have any pro tips for an individual who’s been told they’re likely developing diabetes (type still undetermined)?”
To start - the treatment for types 1 and 3c are TOTALLY DIFFERENT from Type 2; and Type 2 is the most common version of DM - Diabetes Mellitus (I’m assuming you’re NOT talking about any of the four types of DI - Diabetes Insipidus).
Following is an outline of the types of DM, with some basics on causes and treatments, which I wrote for a similar query. At the end is a summary of how to PREVENT the development of T2 from “pre-diabetes” (assuming what you’re “developing” IS T2).
DM - Diabetes Mellitus - refers to one of three conditions that cause BG (Blood Glucose) levels to become elevated. The three basic types of DM are T1 (Type 1), T2 (Type 2), and T3c (Type 3c). People with these diseases are all D's (Diabetics), but more specifically - T1's, T2's, and T3c's.

Type 1 diabetes (under 10% of DM patients), which USED to be called Juvenile Diabetes or IDDM (Insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus) is caused by one of a group of genetic anomalies in the HLA (Human Leukocyte Antigen) complex on Chromosome 6 of the DNA structure; in those that have one of these anomalies, a "trigger" is needed to start the disease process - the known triggers (not all are known) so far are several different viruses (enteroviruses, rubella and mumps are some of the most common – but there are many).
When triggered, the disease causes the immune system to destroy a tiny portion (about 1% to 2%) of the pancreatic tissue - the part that produces the hormones insulin and amylin. We can live without amylin - but NOT without insulin. Until the extraction and purification of insulin from animal pancreases in 1921, ALL T1's died shortly after dx's (diagnosis). T1 is known as an "autoimmune" disease - because it's caused by the immune system attacking its own body, which it's not supposed to do.
T1, while typically occurring in children (and being the most common chronic childhood disease) can occur at any age. Currently, the "median age" at dx's is 14 years old. The short summary of T1 is that people with T1 can produce no insulin because the insulin-producing cells of the pancreas have been destroyed.
T1 is a rapid developing disease; but there is a slow-forming version usually seen in adults called LADA (Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults), which is also referred to as T1.5 (Type 1.5) - which while in common usage, is not a valid diagnostic code. Ultimately, LADA is simply a slower-forming version of T1.
Neonatal DM (far less than 1% of all cases of DM) is generally “lumped in” with T1; but researchers and some docs consider it to be it’s own disease. In any event, this type occurs in infancy – even prior to birth in some cases, but within the first 6 months of life. It is the result of lack of insulin – and/or poor response to glucose-stimulation of insulin response; in both cases, the result is too little insulin. There are two sub-sub types of this condition – permanent and “transient”; in cases of transient NDM, the condition may “go away” – only to return later. This sub-type is caused by one of several single genetic markers – making it a monogenic sub-type of DM.
Type 2 diabetes (over 90% of DM patients), which USED to be called Maturity Onset Diabetes or NIDDM (Non-Insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus) is caused by cellular resistance to the action of insulin. In essence, even though a T2 produces plenty of insulin (actually, a lot more than non-Diabetics do), it doesn't work right. Insulin's job is to move glucose (a simple sugar) from the bloodstream (the body's delivery system) into the cells of the body, which need it for fuel. When this transfer is too slow, the BG level gets too high - and the cells of the body don't get the fuel they need as fast as it's needed. T2 is caused by an anomalous sequencing of genetic variants located throughout over 80 areas of the human genome, but there are so far THREE that are absolutely confirmed as causative. All three are located near IRS1 (Insulin Receptor Substrate 1) on chromosome 2 of the human genome; these are SNPs (Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms) rs2943650, rs2943634, and rs2972146. These all cause the underlying biochemical issue of IR (Insulin Resistance), but also, they pre-dispose the carrier to a tendency to gain weight easily, and fatigue readily.
As T2 is developing… the patient experiences hunger for longer periods than they should due to the delayed delivery of glucose into the cells; even as they’re eating a large meal, these patients will experience hunger (polyphagia) that will drive them to eat more than they should need… because the glucose isn’t getting where it’s supposed to go, and the cells signal the brain that they’re “hungry” even when there’s plenty of glucose in the system. Later, when the patient is sleeping - the gluco-regulatory system “catches up” with the “extra” glucose in the blood, and stores it - as fat tissue. This is why so many (70% to 80%) of T2’s are overweight at diagnosis. It’s a SYMPTOM – not a cause; though excess weight increases insulin resistance.
Also… the lack of fuel getting into the cells leaves those cells short on fuel - and that causes fatigue. This in turn will lead to a more sedentary existence. Again, it’s a symptom - not a cause.
GDM - Gestational Diabetes Mellitus - is simply T2 that appears during the physiological stress of pregnancy. While the patient has typically not yet developed the symptoms of T2 - their body is susceptible to it, and the hormonal stress of pregnancy “pushes” their gluco-regulatory system “over the edge” into diabetic BG levels. The placenta that supports the foetus produces a number of hormones that inhibit the mother’s cellular response to insulin - and that simply exacerbates her inherent susceptibility to T2. BUT… generally, after giving birth (and discharging the placenta), the mother will return to “normal” (non-diabetic) BG levels… BUT… the vast majority of women that suffer GDM will go on to develop T2 later in life (about 75% within 25 years… or 50% within 15 years).
There are also 11 slightly different versions of T2 known as MODY (Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young) each of which are associated with a single genetic anomaly in various places in the human genome. These are very rare, and usually not as severe as traditional T2. Many docs also consider these to be completely different types of DM, rather than sub-types of T2.

All forms of T2 are primarily treated with “diet” and “exercise”. These are, unfortunately, very vague references to some very specific needs. In short - by “diet”, we mean carbohydrate limitation (because carbs are the primary source of glucose in our diets), combined with regular BG testing - to learn how many carbs the individual patient can “tolerate”; no two T2s are the same in this regard… the severity of the insulin resistance varies - A LOT - from patient to patient, so each must learn their personal limits.
By “exercise”, we mean ANY type of PA - Physical Activity… but AT LEAST 4 or 5 days a week, and AT LEAST 35 or 30 minutes per day; more is better. The POINT of this PA is that it IMPROVES cellular response to insulin - in other words, “exercise” addresses the underlying biochemical failing, making the insulin the body makes more effective. This benefit lasts as long as the patient is getting REGULAR PA. ANY activity you enjoy and can stick to is helpful… walking, biking, swimming, gardening; the “trick” is to find something you like and can maintain.
Type 3c diabetes (less than 1% of DM patients), or Pancreatogenic DM, is caused by disease or injury to the pancreas that induces the condition - and is very similar to T1 in that insulin production is destroyed or severely limited. Physical injury or one of several diseases can cause this (pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis, pancreatic cancer, chromohaemotosis, et al). In any event - it is ultimately treated like T1 - with insulin injections.

To diagnose which type you have, the T3c is easily dismissed if you don't have one of the diseases or conditions that cause it. But T2 and T1 MUST be tested for - fortunately, that is easy. The C-peptide test is a test for a type of peptide (Connecting peptide) that is produced in conjunction with, and proportionately to, insulin. Since T1's produce virtually no insulin - they also have little or no C-peptide. T2's, however, have more-than-normal amounts of insulin and C-peptide. So a test for the presence of C-peptide (a simple blood test, and very cheap) is used as a proxy for an insulin test (a complex blood test, and very expensive). Dx'g (diagnosing) by age is a bad method, and is the reason the vast majority of LADA T1's are mis-dx'd as T2's at first - until they continue to sicken (T2 treatments and meds do NOT work for T1's) and the doc's finally do the C-peptide test and start insulin treatment.

There are also several tests for autoantibodies, which may be present in T1s… but often, they are no longer present by the time the testing is done. But doctors often have these tests performed just to “confirm” the C- peptide result; unfortunately, a negative test result is NOT a guarantee that the patient is not T1.
In all forms of DM, the most common symptoms are polydipsia (excessive thirst), polyurea (excessive urination) polyphagia (extended hunger) and fatigue. These are ALL caused by elevated BG levels and lack of fuel to the cells. When your blood retains too much glucose that isn't getting into your body's cells, your kidneys try to "screen" it out - dumping the glucose into your bladder, which needs water to dilute it into, which becomes urine. Your kidneys "steal" the fluids from your body tissue, and use it to make sweetened urine; you get dehydrated, and have to pee a lot. In T1, there is usually a lot of un-sought weight-loss immediately before diagnosis - because without the fuel your body's cells need, your body fuels itself with its own fat and muscle tissue - "burning" those off instead of using the glucose in your bloodstream. In T2 - the weight loss usually doesn't happen, and in any event, never to the extent it does in T1. BUT... in LADA T1's, the weight loss, if any, may be very slow.
SO… what you eat, while it may contribute to, or forestall, the onset of T2, will NOT “cause” ANY type of DM. Only T2 is a metabolic disorder - T1 and T3c are caused by loss of insulin production. And T2 is CAUSED by genetic bad luck, and a resulting biochemical failure in the gluco-regulatory response - that is NOT related to what you eat, although limiting carbs is an excellent tactic for improving BG levels in those that carry the genetic markers… or anyone that thinks they may, and wants to forestall it’s onset.
Finally, for those with “pre-diabetes”, or “developing” T2… here’s a good intro from NIH on how to prevent the onset of full-blown T2, geared to those with high risk factors for it - and those with “pre-diabetes” (a condition akin to being “a little bit pregnant”): Preventing Type 2 Diabetes | NIDDK
Another site on prevention, from the ADA: Risk Test | ADA
Another from Mayo Clinic: Diabetes prevention: 5 tips for taking control
A final one from the endocrinologists: Type 2 Diabetes Prevention: Here's What You Can Do

question: Is diabetes freedom a legitimate solution to diabetes?
a_text:
Diabetic Freedom – Is it a Scam or the Real Deal?
Diabetes Freedom has recently been released by the network marketing company called Diabetes Freedom International (DFI). This group claims that their product can cure diabetes, which has raised many questions about the credibility of the program. Is Diabetes Freedom legitimate or just another scam? Let’s explore further to see what DFIs claims are and whether it’s worth your time or not.
Does It Work?
While Diabetes Freedom is not a scam, we’re going to go out on a limb and say that we’re not convinced that there is any special solution to diabetes. If you’ve been diagnosed with diabetes, there are some things you can do to try and control your blood sugar levels; there are also some things you should probably avoid if you don’t want to raise your chances of developing complications down the road. There are lots of different medications for people with type 2 diabetes, as well as for those who have type 1. There are also many natural remedies that have been shown to be effective in helping people keep their blood glucose under control. In other words, there’s no diabetes cure—but some measures will help keep your condition from getting worse than it already is.
How does it work?
Users are provided with an eight-week meal plan that features various hypoallergenic meals for breakfast, lunch and dinner. It is supplemented with suggested snacks and an exercise regimen. To ensure users stick to their diet and develop new eating habits, they are provided with tools to track their calories, carbohydrates and fats daily. The progress of each user is monitored by Diabetic Freedom’s team of certified medical professionals through phone consultations throughout their weight loss journey. Is it safe?: According to its website, Diabetic Freedom does not use any ingredients banned by U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
Instead, its proprietary blend of ingredients work together to reduce appetite while increasing energy levels and metabolism so that users can lose up to 10 pounds in two weeks without feeling hungry or fatigued. All ingredients used in its products are natural and have been tested under FDA guidelines.
Do You need To Commit to The Diet Long Term?
One of my pet peeves about many diets, is that they force you to stay on them for life. While some are manageable long term and can be used as part of a healthy lifestyle, others require so much effort that once you start slipping up, it’s hard to get back into eating healthily again. Diabetic freedom seems like a great way to have your cake and eat it too, but if you don’t commit to staying on the diet permanently, there’s no guarantee that your diabetes will disappear. If I were diabetic, I would want something more concrete than freedom from diabetes.
What Will Happen if I Don’t Follow the Program As Instructed?
You’ll gain weight, feel sick and out of energy, and feel like you have no hope. And then, you’ll try another program and start feeling bad all over again. You’re diabetic freedom won’t be worth anything if you can’t commit to following through with diet plan. The good news is that it isn’t as hard as you think! You just need to give yourself time to adjust and follow instructions. Remember, your body has been craving sugar for years; cutting it out cold turkey will make you feel awful at first. But stick with it—and stay committed—and soon enough, your body will adjust and you’ll begin feeling better than ever before!
Does Dr. Davis Have Any Supportive Evidence?
Dr. Davis, who holds a Ph.D. in exercise physiology, claims that diabetes freedom is possible for anyone, regardless of age or health status. While he doesn’t outright claim that you can cure your diabetes—rather, his approach uses low-glycemic carbohydrates to stop insulin spikes and control blood sugar levels without medication—many of his clients have experienced similar results. In one clinical study sponsored by Diabetic Freedom, 67 percent of those who followed Dr. Davis’s program were able to reduce their medication usage by an average of 75 percent within 12 weeks. The success rate was even higher among patients with type 2 diabetes: 83 percent were able to decrease their medication use after just three months on Dr. Davis’s plan.
Is there a money back guarantee with this program?
No, but there is an ironclad 90-day guarantee. So if after 90 days you haven’t achieved all of your goals, then you can get a full refund. I think that’s totally fair! Plus, they even give you meal plans and help with accountability via live chat and email. That way they make sure that they take care of their customers even after they have paid for their program. How cool is that?
My Final Thoughts on Diabetic Freedom:
I’ve been using Diabetic Freedom for just over two months now and I must say, I’m very impressed. If you are serious about living a diabetes-free life, then definitely give DF a try. There is an entire community of users who support each other in addition to daily email tips. The way DF works (it varies from person to person) but most have said that they have seen improvements in their blood sugar within weeks! While it may not work for everyone, it certainly seems worth a shot if you’re ready to take control of your health.

question: In the medical field, do you have prospects for diabetes treatment?
a_text:
In the medical field, do you have prospects for diabetes treatment?
Diabetes mellitus is a condition in which the amount of glucose in the blood (blood sugar) is too high. The process of moving glucose from the blood into the body’s cells relies on a hormone called insulin. Insulin is made by the pancreas, a gland lying behind the stomach. Insulin helps glucose to enter cells, for example, in muscles, liver and fat tissue. When insulin levels are too low or are ineffective, blood glucose levels can raise, which may result in diabetes. There are two main types of diabetes, type 1 and type 2.
Type 1 diabetes (T1DM) typically appears in children and happens because of a lack of insulin. It’s caused when the insulin-producing cells in the pancreas are destroyed by an autoimmune response. The reason for this is still not well understood, but those with a genetic susceptibility are most at risk. There have also been suggestions that viral infections may trigger the process. This type of diabetes is treated with regular insulin injections and is also known as insulin dependent diabetes.
Type 2 diabetes (T2DM) is known as non-insulin dependent diabetes. Insulin is produced, but the muscles that would normally respond by taking up glucose to use as energy storage become insulin resistant, causing glucose levels in the blood to increase. Historically, type 2 diabetes was seen in middle-aged and elderly people and only rarely occurred in young people. Recently, however, it has escalated in all age groups and is now being diagnosed in younger and younger patients including obese adolescents and children.

question: Why is there no clear correlation between refined sugar consumption and diabetes?
a_text: There is, in fact, a clear and consistent correlation between refined sugar consumption and diabetes. But there is no compelling evidence showing that sugar causes diabetes. The evidence This figure comes from a very comprehensive review of studies in humans.[1] Each blue square represents a single study. The statistic reported is called relative risk. When the blue square is to the right of the vertical line, the study showed that higher sugar consumption was associated with diabetes. Horizontal lines are error bars; these show the degree of uncertainty in the results. In some cases, those horizontal lines are big, meaning that the study isn’t very precise. In other cases, the horizontal lines are too small to be seen, these are the most precise studies. Overall, there's a slight tendency for people who drink a lot of sugar sweetened beverages to be more likely to become diabetic but the effect is small. The next chart shows studies in which sugar intake was estimated before the people became diabetic. Again, the squares represent individual studies. All but one of them, showed that higher sugar intake predicted the eventual development of diabetes but the degree of risk was small. The literature on this topic is vast and mostly consistent. People who eat a lot of sugar are slightly more likely to be diabetic or eventually become diabetic. Many of these studies tried to control for obesity, socioeconomic status, total energy intake, other foods eaten, age, gender, education, ethnicity/race, and much more. The results have been as consistent as one could hope for in a biomedical topic. So why isn’t this correlation valid? All of those studies are correlational. There don’t appear to be any experiments in which either people or lab rats were given reasonable amounts of sugars for a long period of time. Correlation does not imply causation.[2] Just because diabetics have been eating/drinking more sugar than non-diabetics doesn’t establish that sugar causes diabetes. Once you establish a correlation, the usual next step is to confirm it with an experiment. There are some short term trials, up to 6 weeks, showing that replacing glucose-only starch with fructose-containing sucrose altered blood glucose and insulin levels [3] but that isn’t the same as showing that sugar causes diabetes. The absence of experiments on lab rats surprises me. There’s a large number of studies in which scientists fed lab rats sugars but no one seems to have looked at diabetes. There are lots of studies in which lab rats were fed absurd amounts of pure fructose but very few people eat much pure fructose.[4] High-fructose corn syrups in soft drinks contain only 55–65% fructose.[5] There is another reason why rat studies might be helpful. Insofar as I can tell, all studies of sugars and diabetes involve asking people how much they ate over one or several days. That kind of data is inaccurate. Overweight people tend to under-report how much they ate and most people can only guess as to how big that sandwich or steak they had was.[6] [7]This chart shows how unreliable this kind of data is.[8] Rats aren’t the same as people but you can run controlled experiments with them and you can closely measure how much they eat, something that is hard to do with people. Opposing views Scientists disagree on this issue. Some think sugar is toxic:[9] [10] But other scientists think that the scientific evidence for those claims isn’t all that strong. One article looked at the evidence and concluded that there is no compelling evidence that sugars cause diabetes.[11] If there are any adverse effects of sugar, they are due entirely to the calories it provides, and it is therefore indistinguishable from any other caloric food. Excess total energy consumption seems far more likely to be the cause of obesity and diabetes. Although many individuals can lose a substantial amount of weight and thereby also delay the onset of diabetes, to do so has relied on an overall reduction in energy consumption. Thus, if reduced energy intake is desirable, all caloric foods are candidates. A reduction in consumption of added sugars should head the list because they provide no essential nutrients. There’s a similar story for alcohol. Nobody knows for sure whether it extends life.[12] [13]Similar issues appear for other kinds of nutritional studies. You can get an excellent discussion in this article: [14] Personal involvement Back in the 20th Century, I published papers arguing sugars produce overeating in rats on account of their sensory effects, rather than their nutritional effects. Here’s a few of them. question: Will Bernie Sanders' “Medicare for All” bill require obese people to lose weight to mitigate the cost to taxpayers of treating chronic conditions linked to obesity like diabetes and heart disease?

Sanders is talking up the idea that when folks get regular care instead of letting their problems fester into emergencies, it could help to bend the cost curve.

When you look at it this way, regular basic health care might cost something at the time, but it can also prevent minor issues from becoming major ones.

No, you’re not going to be priced out of your health care if M4A becomes reality- likely you’ll end up paying less than you do today.
