Medicare for all will insure… ALL of us. ALL.
It isn’t called ‘medicare for the rich’, or even ‘medicare for some’. The idea that you should be worried about being ‘priced out of the market’ for universal health care is inconsistent with the idea that it is universal health care. The whole point to UHC is that you can’t be priced out of it.

question: What is the best advice that people never hear about diabetes?
a_text:
As a retired RN, I knew alot about diabetes. I saw people lose their legs, one toe at a time. I saw a close friend die in the middle of a kidney dialysis treatment. I saw plenty of blind people. I knew this was a bad disease.
One day I heard a pediatric diabetic educator. She taught me the most important lesson of all the experts I'd seen over the years.
She was teaching a young boy about why it was important to keep his blood sugar under control. She had the usual models showing how much sugar was in an apple, a piece of cake, a serving of chicken. She had set a glass of water on the table. She also had a frozen popsicle, unwrapped in a glass, and she had a glass of maple syrup.
At the end of her talk she asked the boy to take each glass and pour it into another glass. The water flowed freely. The melted popsicle flowed pretty fast but left a residue on the glass it was in. The maple syrup took its sweet time and coated the glass it was in.
She explained how the more sugary the liquid was the thicker it was. She related it to human blood getting “thicker” with sugar and decreased the speed of flow AND decreased how much oxygen could fit into the already sugar logged liquid. She went onto use drawings to show how the “blood” couldn't get into the tiny blood vessels in our eyes, kidneys, toes, lungs. The area that blood couldn't get to died, as in toes.
It was definitely graphic but the young boy and his Mom really responded to the graphics. The boy learned early on his food choices directly affected his life. Great teacher!

question: If people say drinking fruit juice can cause diabetes, what is the difference with eating fruit?
a_text:
Okay, I'll explain the difference as simply as I can. Just conduct the following experiment on two consecutive days.
On day one, drink a nice big 16-oz glass of orange juice in the morning.
On day two, have eight oranges for breakfast.
What? You couldn't finish the oranges?
They both have equivalent amounts of sugar, comparable to soda. But the oranges also come with fiber and bulk, which is why you probably balked after your second or third orange.
Plus, that fiber slows the absorption of sugar into the bloodstream so that the body is better equipped to handle it. And the orange itself takes time to digest.
Orange Juice - Not as Healthy as you Think
But with that orange juice, you may as well be mainlining the sugar. It goes straight to the bloodstream, except for the fructose in it (sucrose is 50% fructose), because humans can't metabolize fructose. Hummingbirds can; people can't.
So fructose goes to the liver instead, where it's stored as liver fat until it can be converted to glucose for energy. Repeated high doses of fructose — the average American consumes 17 teaspoons of added sugar per day (and this doesn't include the sugar in whole fruit) — lead to non-alcoholic fatty liver, metabolic syndrome, and type 2 diabetes.
Here's what fatty liver looks like. Kind of like a burnt potato chip in a 2-D rendering.
The liver is capable of handling moderate helpings of fruit in a well-balanced diet. It can't handle the massive amount of fructose in the standard American diet.
Incidentally, 90% of the refined sugar Americans consume comes from ultra-processed food. So even if you forego the juice and the soda, you're not out of the woods. You can still be at risk for diabetes. 37% of Americans have metabolic syndrome, or prediabetes.
‘Ultra-processed foods’ contribute 90% of added sugar in U.S. diet, study finds
More Than One-Third of Americans Have Dangerous Metabolic Syndrome

question: I saw this on House M.D. and I wanted to know if it was real. Can you replace urine with Apple juice to fake a spike in blood sugar?
a_text:
For about fifteen minutes, yes.
Glucometer
If you try to pass apple juice for urine to fake a blood sugar spike, your sample will be flagged as positive, there was glucose in your urine. Any glucose in urine at all implies your plasma sugar is above 15 mmol/L, kidneys resorb that much. If this is an ER case the next logical step would be to determine your plasma glucose to see just how bad is it. Maybe they'll use a glucometer for a quck reading, perhaps they will judge you can wait longer and draw a proper blood sample, but the result will be the same. Unless you're a diabetic with serious hyperglycemia and didn't have to fake anything that reading will be below 11.1 mmol/L, more likely half that. At that point they excluded sugar spike and soon someoe will come to a conclusion the sample was mislabeled.
They will absolutely think they have someone else with a sugar spike and possibly have a bunch of people re-tested for no good reason, but that's on you and your little faking. Yay you.
It’s also possible the laboratory will figure out the fakery outright. The smaller the laboratory the more likely it is.

question: Was diabetes a known condition in ancient times?
a_text:
Epiphaniae medicorum, uroscopy and ring of flasks (Diagnosing diabetes: a wee taste of honey
)
… “no essential part of the drink is absorbed by the body while great masses of the flesh are liquefied into urine.”- Aretaeus of Cappadocia[1]
Although it seems to have gained notoriety only recently as increasing numbers of people across the globe have fallen prey to the disease, countless brilliant minds have played a part in the fascinating history of diabetes mellitus. Scientists and physicians have been chronicling this devastating medical condition for more than 3,000 years, from the origins of its discovery to the dramatic breakthroughs in its treatment. In antiquity, a diagnosis of diabetes was likely a death sentence.
Cedar wood panel depicting Hesy-Ra (Hesy-Ra - Wikipedia
)
The first known mention of diabetes symptoms was in the Ebers Papyrus 1552 B.C., where Hesy-Ra a third dynasty physician (whose title was Wer-ibeh-senjw, meaning either "Great one of the ivory cutters" or "Great one of the dentists"), documented frequent urination as a symptom of a mysterious disease that also caused emaciation. Hesy-Ra mentions the “too great emptying of the urine'.
The following mixture was prescribed for the treatment of polyuria (excessive urination): ‘A measuring glass filled with Water from the Bird pond, Elderberry, Fibres of the asit plant, Fresh Milk, Beer-Swill, Flower of the Cucumber, and Green Dates”.[2]
It's unclear whether the condition described was excessive urine (polyuria), which may have been symptomatic of diabetes, or increased frequency of urine, resulting from a urinary tract infection[3] . Urinary troubles were corrected with rectal injections of olive oil, honey, sweet beer, sea salt, and seeds of the wonderfruit.[4]
Egyptian medicine influenced the medical practices of neighboring cultures, including the culture of ancient Greece. Although the Greek physician Hippocrates, the father of medicine, did not specifically mention diabetes in his writings, there are accounts in the Hippocratic writings that are consistent with the signs and symptoms of diabetes.[5] There are references to excessive urinary flow with wasting of the body. Hippocrates promoted the concept of preventive medicine, stressimg the influence of diet, exercise, and lifestyle on health.[6]
(Origin of surgery Sushruta (Origin of surgery Sushruta - Fancy Frindle
)
The ancient Indian physician, Sushruta (6th century BC), and the surgeon Charaka (400–500 A.D.) were able to identify the two types, later to be named Type I and Type II diabetes.[7] Sushruta called diabetes the disease of madhu-meha, i.e., sweet urine.[8] The first clinical test of diabetes was devised in Ancient India, where patients exhibiting the common diabetes symptoms described above, had their urine analyzed with the help of ants.[9] If the sugar-loving ants came rushing to the urine, a diagnosis of “madhumeha” was given, indicating the patient had “honey urine”, with elevated levels of glucose in the urine.[10]
Another ancient Ayurveda physician, Charaka, who lived in the 3rd century BCE called diabetes the disease of prameha, referring to abnormally high outputs of urine.[11] Both physicians advocated abstaining from sweet foods and reducing the intake of rice and other grains as part of the treatment of diabetes.[12]
Apollonius of Memphis (A history of Diabetes timeline)
There are two contenders for coining the term diabetes meaning to pass through. The first is Apollonius of Memphis, around 250 BC, while the second is Demetrius of Apamea (1st century BCE).[13] Apollonius of Memphis. is credited with naming the disorder for its top symptom: the excessive passing of urine through the body’s system.[14] Demetrius, likened polyuria to the siphoning of wine between pots—a practice now called "racking," which has long been used during fermentation to remove the sediment of dead yeast and promote proper aging.[15]
Caelius Aurelianus prepared a Latin version of the works of Soranus, including in the index a subject heading for "Diabetes”. Caelius quotes Apollonius of Memphis as separating two forms of dropsy, one marked by retention of fluid and the other by the inability to retain fluid; the patient discharges whatever he drinks as if it were passed through a pipe. Caelius Aurelianus continues by stating that Demetrius distinguishes this disease from dropsy in which any fluid that is drunk is discharged as urine. Demetrius calls this condition diabetes.[16]
Aulus (Aurelius) Cornelius Celsus, a Roman physician, was credited with the first recording of the cardinal signs of inflammation, which included calor (warmth), dolor (pain), tumor (swelling), and rubor (redness and hyperemia).[17] He describes a condition likely to be diabetes, calling it "excessive pouring out of urine" causing "emaciation and danger”.[18]
In the first century A.D., ancient Greek physician Aretaeus vividly described the destructive nature of an illness which he named diabetes derived from the Greek word “siphon” (meaning flowing through).[19]
Diabetes is … not very frequent ... being a melting down of the flesh and limbs into urine … for the patients never stop making water, but the flow is incessant, as if from the opening of aqueducts. It consists in the flesh and bones running together into the urine … the illness develops very slowly. The nature of the disease is chronic, and it takes a long period to form; but the patient does not live long once the disease is fully established; for the melting is rapid, the death speedy. Moreover life is disgusting and painful; thirst, unquenchable … and one cannot stop them either from drinking or making water".[20]
Diabetes indeed appears to have been a death sentence in the ancient era: Aretaeus did attempt to treat it, but could not provide a good prognosis. He commented that "life (with diabetes) is short, disgusting and painful”.[21] In 164 AD, building upon Aretaeus’ assessment, Greek physician, Galen of Pergamum, categorized diabetes as an ailment of the kidneys.[22]
The Origins of Diabetes | St. Hope Foundation
For several hundred years, the treatises of Aretaeus and Galen remained the definitive reference for the diagnosis of diabetes, but offered no cures. To the east, Chinese physicians described the disease similarly, labeling it xiao ke (wasting and thirsting), a term still used today.[23] Xiaoke tea, a traditional Chinese treatment for diabetes mellitus was thought to lower blood glucose concentrations.[24]
As the Middle Ages began, diabetes was known as the “pissing evil”[25] , commonly diagnosed by “water tasters”, who tasted the urine of people thought to have diabetes to see if the excretion was sweet like honey.[26] Avicenna (980–1037 A.D.), the great Persian physician, in The Canon of Medicine not only referred to abnormal appetite and the decline of sexual functions, but observed diabetic gangrene but also concocted a mixture of seeds (lupin, fenugreek, zedoary) as a panacea.[27]
Thomas Willis in the late 1600s added the term mellitus or "from honey" to separate the condition from diabetes insipidus, which is also associated with frequent urination.[28] Willis was infamous for his diagnosis of diabetes, which involved tasting the urine of his patients.[29] He associated diabetes with depression (“diabetes is caused by melancholy”), an observation that was only rediscovered three centuries later.[30]
With little understanding of pathophysiology, early remedies for diabetes included diverse and interesting prescriptions like “oil of roses, dates, raw quinces and gruel, jelly of viper’s flesh, broken red coral, sweet almonds and fresh flowers of blind nettles” representing a variety of beliefs and practices of the times.[31] The prescribed treatment was exercise, which is consistent with medical advice for today, but with one difference: the preferred method of exercise was horseback riding.[32] It was thought that this would decrease urination frequency.
Later, in the pre-insulin era, calorie restriction reigned supreme, and graphic accounts of the terminal gasping and sighing and sweet smell (ketosis) surrounding the patient in a diabetic coma abound in the volumes written on the disease.[33]
Research published in the journal ‘Nature’ reveals that the likelihood of non-African Homo sapiens developing conditions, particularly auto-immune disorders, which can be determined by Neanderthal alleles. DNA sequencing was conducted on a recent skeletal discovery from Denisova Cave, indicating that what were considered modern diseases originated in our Neanderthal ancestors.[34] The diseases included type two diabetes, Crohn's disease, lupus and biliary cirrhosis.[35]
The deep roots of diabetes
The diagnosis of diabetes mellitus from skeletal remains is very difficult given the complexity of the disease and the fact that there are no pathological skeletal characteristics exclusively associated with the condition.[36] Skeletal identification of diabetes mellitus may only be possible through differential diagnosis, when several pathological changes are present. Skeletal and dental changes associated with diabetes mellitus include Charcot's joint (neuropathic arthropathy), osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH, or Forestier's disease), adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder), dental caries, periodontal disease, and antemortem tooth loss.[37]
It should not be understood that Neanderthals had diabetes. Type 2 diabetes is a disease of the modern world, borne of a mismatch between modern, unhealthy lifestyles and a metabolism that, for the vast majority of our evolutionary history, existed in an environment where food was relatively scarce and lots of physical activity was necessary to survive.[38] In the harsh environment of the Ice Age, even individuals carrying genes that contribute to diabetes when food is plentiful and sedentary lifestyles are common are unlikely to develop diabetes.
Skeletal remains of an adult male from the Egyptian archaeological site of Dayr al Barsha dated to the Middle Kingdom (ca. 2055–1650 BC), display a myriad of pathological conditions that, when considered together, indicate the presence of diabetes mellitus.[39] This diagnosis represents the earliest, and possibly the only recorded, archaeological Raf inhibitor skeletal evidence for this disease.
(Ancient Mummy Suffered Rare And Painful Disease
)
Around 2,900 years ago, an ancient Egyptian man, likely in his 20s, passed away after suffering from a rare, cancer-like disease that may also have left him with a type of diabetes. His mummy showed telltale signs that he suffered from Hand-Schuller-Christian disease an enigmatic condition in which Langerhans cells, a type of immune cell found in the skin, multiply rapidly.[40] They tend to replace normal structure of the bone and all other soft tissues.
The disease seems to have taken a terrible toll on the ancient man’s body, as it destroyed parts of his skeleton, leaving lytic lesions throughout his spine and skull.[41] Scans also indicated what looks like a giant hole in his skull’s frontal-parietal bone, and destruction of a section of one of his eye sockets, known as the orbital wall. The effects of the disease would have been excruciating and would have affected the man’s appearance. In addition, it may have led him to suffer from a form of diabetes. The scans show that his sella turcica, part of the skull that holds the pituitary gland, is shallow, which suggests that this gland was also affected by the disease.[42]
Researchers believe the condition could have lead to diabetes insipius. The condition would have made it difficult for his kidneys to conserve water, something that would have worsened the man’s predicament.[43] In all likelihood, he suffered from continuous thirst and hunger, urinating frequently.
Hatsheput (Metropolitan Museum of Art - Wikipedia
)
Recent examination of a mummy considered to be Hatshesput (Pharoah of the XVIIIth dynasty 1503 and 1482BC) suggests she probably died of an infection caused by an abscessed tooth, with complications from advanced bone cancer and possibly diabetes.[44] Amenhotep III, the ninth pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt, may have suffered from diabetes as well.[45]
Archaeological evidence indicates that certain groups of Paleo-Indians maintained an arctic-like hunter-gatherer life-style in temperate areas of North America ranging from Wyoming to Arizona. This life-style featured a reliance on unpredictable big game species as a major food source. However, at this time, big game species were becoming extinct. It is hypothesized that those Paleo-Indians who relied on big game as a food source developed a “thrifty” genotype,[46] that allowed a selective advantage during the periods of fasting that occurred between big game kills.
Insulin resistance has previously been proposed as a mechanism for coping with variable food intake during evolution. Neel's thrifty gene hypothesis postulates that cycles of feast and famine selected for a “quick insulin trigger” (postprandial hyperinsulinemia) as a mechanism to increase fat stores during food abundance and available during food scarcity.[47]
There is a high prevalence of (Non-Insulin Dependent Diabetes (NIDDM) susceptible genotypes in several distinct populations: American Indians, Australian Aborigines, and Pacific Islanders.[48] The susceptible genotype may have been selected into these populations because of unusually frequent food shortages that occurred during the initial colonization of 'new worlds'. NIDDM has been shown to have a strong genetic component that may include a 'thrifty' genotypes.[49] The 'thrifty' genotypes may have once allowed founding populations to survive feast' and 'famine' conditions for several generations. With an assured food supply and a sedentary lifestyle, however, the 'thrifty' genotype(s) becomes disadvantageous, leading to obesity, increased insulin resistance, beta cell decompensation, and NIDDM.[50]
New DNA techniques will spark archeology revolution, expert says
During the same time period, across the Atlantic Ocean, it is believed that inhabitants began to exhibit symptoms of what would eventually be classified as Juvenile diabetes. During a 1000 year climatic reversal known as the Younger Dryas, temperatures dropped by 10 degrees Fahrenheit, causing those who did not die from the artic conditions to move South.[51] Researchers from Mount Sinai School of Medicine of New York suggest that some individuals adapted to the extreme conditions. High levels of blood glucose prevent cells and tissue form forming ice crystals. Basically, Type 1 diabetes prevented some from freezing to death.[52]
Food during the last Ice Age was almost certainly limited, meaning that dietary blood sugar likely followed suit. Therefore, the insulin of a diabetic from this epoch may have never come close to reaching dangerous levels.
The following quote is from Sharon Moalem:
Imagine that some small group of people had a different response to the cold. Faced with year-round frigid temperatures, their insulin supply slowed, allowing their blood sugar to rise somewhat. As in the wood frog, this would have lowered the freezing point of their blood. They urinated frequently, to keep internal water levels low… Suppose these people used their brown fat to burn that oversupply of sugar in their blood to create heat. Perhaps they even produced additional clotting factor to repair tissue damage caused by particularly deep cold snaps. It’s not hard to imagine that these people might have had enough of an advantage over other humans… to make it more likely that they would survive long enough to reach reproductive age.”[53]
Many in the medical community are skeptical, asserting that the study fails to account for dangerous complications such as ketoacidosis and early death.[54] However, since the average age of death was 25, those with high glucose would not have lived long enough to succomb to complications. They would however, despite the extreme conditions, live long enough to reproduce, resulting in genetic adaptations over a few generations.[55]
While this may sound highly speculative, there’s actually a decent amount of evidence to support the notion. Lab rats essentially become diabetic (that is, they grow resistant to their own insulin) when exposed to cold temperatures.[56]
More Northern Hemisphere inhabitants are diagnosed with diabetes between November and February than between June and September, theoretically due to the noticable drop in temperature during the former period.[57] Almost invariably, children are diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes during the late fall as temperatures drop. An extensive study of U.S. veterans, revealed that not only do the subjects’ blood sugar levels spike while winter is at hand, but that those who hail from environments with a great deal of variation in seasonal temperature (ie: colder districts) had a particularly extreme physiological contrast in this regard.[58]

question: What would happen if I were to inject insulin?
a_text:
The fact that you are asking this question at all strongly suggests that you are not diabetic. Therefore you should not do it!
If you were to do so when you don’t need it, or overdose when you are diabetic, the result could be minor (sweating, shaking, confusion) ranging to brain damage, ranging to death.
There are zero recreational “benefits” to injecting insulin.
Diabetics who take insulin take classes beforehand. They take blood tests several times a day to measure their blood glucose levels. They are under a doctor’s supervision. They follow a diet to eat low amounts of sugars, and low amounts of other carbohydrates. You should not be using insulin unless you are doing all of the above.

question: Why can't blood be taken from the earlobe instead of the finger for blood sugar tests? There are far fewer nerves in the ear lobe than the fingertip and a prick there is almost completely painless.
a_text:
Note: this answer contains references to, and pictures of, needles and bleeding body parts. If this upsets you, you should turn back now. Since the first image comes up as a thumbnail on the feed, here is an unrelated picture of my cat. (Though I expect he would like to think of his paws as full of needles.)
Onwards.
Since I always wanted to dedicate myself to furthering medicine, and it’s looking less and less likely that I’ll get back to medical school, I shall undertake this experiment for you, OP.
We’re starting with a fresh lancet (important). My lancets here have little plastic caps to minimise the chances of accidental injury.
Lancets, as well as syringes, get disposed of in a yellow sharps container. I put in an order for one every month with the rest of my medications, and pick it up at the pharmacy at the same time, and when it’s full I email the city council to arrange a pickup, and they collect it from my doorstep. (I usually wait till I have two or three full ones to arrange a collection.) I’m not sure what the process is like in other countries (or indeed, other towns).
Don’t worry, that black thing is just a bit of fluff, not a dead spider (nor a live one).
My finger pricker has 8 depth settings. I usually have it set to 4 for my fingers. I googled “is the skin on your earlobes thicker than the skin on your fingers” and various variations, but couldn’t get an answer. I’m going to try it on 3, but I may need to increase it.
I have one sterile wipe left...which is unfortunately two years out of date. They’re expensive, and I pretty much only test at home, so I usually just wash my hands really well with antibacterial soap. I guess we’ll try that on my ear.
Damn, I already need to buy test strips soon. I’m supposed to get them free, but my doctors are being weird lately, and I’ve been paying £15 a month from eBay.
My meter is compact, and it won’t connect to the app on my phone anymore (I really need a new one) but it holds the last five readings. They’re all over the place, but mostly higher than I want, because I had a hyperosmolar hyperglycaemic state (HHS) last week - a high-sugar medical emergency that I had to go to hospital for.
OK, we can do this.
Setting 3 didn’t even bleed. Let’s try 4.
4 got me a tiny bit of blood, but not enough - my machine gives an error reading if there’s not enough blood on the strip. Trying 5.
5 gave a decent amount! Better than a finger. I’ll have to remember that.
Hmm. Still high. Not close to “hospitalisation required” high, but higher than I want. It really needs to be under 10. Under 8 would be better, but this close to an HHS, and with a Crohn’s flareup, I’ll take anything under 10 as a win. 13.1 isn’t the 34.whatever I tested last week, which sent me into hospital, but it’s not good either.
I’m a little surprised that pricking my earlobe didn’t hurt at all! I didn’t even feel it. It’s surprising because I sometimes get pimples on my ear, which occasionally bleed, and those do hurt. And getting my ears pierced was excruciating the first time, though that was almost 30 years ago. I let them close up during the pandemic, and was definitely not looking forward to getting them repierced, but perhaps it won’t hurt as much as I was expecting.
For the sake of comparison, I did a finger prick too. I like to use the side of my ring finger - it bleeds better and hurts less than my other fingers.
Now, that’s startling. A difference of 1.7 in five minutes is quite a lot. Admittedly, I did eat right before testing, and it’s possible that in five minutes, the food hit my bloodstream. Still, such a stark difference makes me wonder if earlobe testing is less reliable than fingers.
Overall, while I found it a bit awkward - I definitely needed a mirror and good light, and it took me a bit longer than usual to get things organised and I worried that my blood would dry up or my meter would turn off before I got the reading - the lack of pain makes me think that perhaps the earlobe is indeed a viable test site. The finger still hurts a little after writing this answer, 15 minutes later. The earlobe never hurt, and doesn’t hurt now. Of course, it’s possible that with repeated testing, it will become painful and/or less easily bled, as scar tissue forms. My other concern was that it might bleed for a longer time - the ear pimples I get sometimes bleed for hours or even days without letting up - but it took about the same time to stop bleeding as a finger.
If it turns out that the readings are reliable, I would be happy to do earlobe testing in future, either as a primary site or as a secondary site when fingers are sore or not wanting to bleed.

Today’s readings:
13.1 mmol/L = 235.8 mg/dL
14.8 mmol/L = 266.4 mg/dL
Referred to in the post (last week’s readings):
34.whatever (let’s call it 34.0) mmol/L = >612.0 mg/dL

question: Can you get diabetes from eating only natural fruits and no artificial sugar?
a_text:
Diabetes is a compound Greek word that means “flowing fountain”.
Of yellow stuff, funnily enough
This is because Ancient Greeks already described a disease whereupon the sufferer would suffer from unquenchable thirst, yet also frequently urinate. Ancient Persians knew of it too and had a rudimentary procedure to diagnose it: spill urine over some rocks and wait. If it attracts insects the result is positive. This is because urine will contain glucose and insects see it as food. This is all in ancient history, around the times of the Trojan war (700 B.C.E. or thereabout).
Processed sugar didn’t become available in Mediterranean until about 2000 years later, in 13th century C.E.
So yes, you can. Easily.

question: Why did a teacher not let me use the bathroom when my blood sugar was high, but she always lets girls go?
a_text:
It isn’t necessarily discrimination, since “girl stuff” isn’t going to the bathroom but rather making sure that young ladies don’t have menstrual blood stain their clothes. That’s pretty simple and is universally accepted. I’m sure that if you were worried about having menstrual blood stain your clothes, you could have appealed based upon those grounds, but I’m also fairly sure that your teacher wouldn’t have believed you. You are in a completely separate boat from those young ladies.
That being said, it is completely inappropriate for a teacher to stop you from using the restroom when you need to go. More importantly, it didn’t have to happen.
Diabetes is a disability and is thus covered under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[1] You should have been able to file for a 504 plan on these grounds.
One of the common accommodations for a student with a 504 plan is, unsurprisingly, more access to restrooms.[2] Thus, you would have been legally protected.
It is unfortunate that more parents and educators don’t know that such issues have a legal remedy which should be implemented before the student leaves the school system in order to make sure that the student can take that plan forward to the university level.

That all being said, I think keeping students from using the restroom unless they have shown themselves to be completely untrustworthy is wrong in my opinion. Students need to use the restroom as necessary. Only students can really determine when that is.

question: Why didn’t ancient humans develop diabetes from eating excess fruit?
a_text:
“Why didn’t ancient humans develop diabetes from eating excess fruit?”
The premise of the question is wrong on a couple of fronts.
First is the notion that humans lived in a Garden of Eden with fields full of fruits ripe for the taking. Though humans may at times have been lucky enough to find small concentrations of fruit, it was not the norm. Human beings are not fundamentally tree climbers like monkeys and could not have gotten to enough fruit to make that a heavy part of the diet on a regular basis.
The other thing is that we must remember that most plants that we eat today are engineered organisms that mankind has created through selective breeding over the last several thousand years. Today we are used to finding an abundance of super sweet fruits grown on farms and filling our grocery-store shelves. Prior to the neolithic revolution, there would not have been nearly so many sugary fruits available. Even as late as classical times, it would still have been hard to eat large amounts of sugar like we do today.
EDIT: Bear in mind, too, that even if you were to gorge yourself on modern fruits, it would be hard to raise your blood sugar level as much as eating a single slice of cake (probably even a single slice of white bread). Modern refined sugar (and refined flour) affects us far more than eating most raw foods.

question: Why can fructose only enter the cells without insulin while other sugar types can't?
a_text:
One of the most basic facts about carbohydrate metabolism is that glucose and fructose are handled differently. For many cells, insulin controls the amount of glucose they take up. But most cells don’t use fructose at all. Instead, around 70% of the fructose you eat is taken up by liver cells (hepatocytes).
The brief answer is that these sugars differ because glucose is carried inside most cells through a transporter molecule that is activated by insulin, but fructose is carried inside liver cells by transporters that don’t require insulin.
The rest of this answer provides more detail. In the last part of the answer, I want to give an evolutionary perspective. I do that because there are several features of this that have baffled me for decades.
Biochemical details
Biological systems aren’t ever simple.
There are several different molecules, transporters, which carry sugars into cells. Many cells rely heavily on one called GLUT4 which transports glucose but not fructose. This transporter is depicted in the lower right of the skeletal muscle cell and adipose (fat) cells in this picture.[1] That transporter is activated by insulin.
Insulin works on this transporter by allowing it to fuse with the cell membrane[2] .
Liver cells, hepatocytes, rely on different transporter molecules called GLUT5 and probably GLUT8 which can transport fructose without insulin (upper left in the diagram).[3][4]Liver cells also take up glucose through the GLUT2 transporter which doesn’t depend on insulin.
But that’s only the beginning. there are several other transporters; each randomly assigned to different organs. (Yes, I did mean to say random.) This chart summarizes them.[5]
This chart summarizes the differences in their function as a picture.[6] The arrows depict triggers (gray, fasting conditions; blue, exercise/physical activity; red, diabetes).
Evolution
The difference between glucose and fructose always struck me as one of the many weird, unexplainable, facts about biology. Both sugars are common in fruits and plant juices, so it’s not obvious why they are handled differently.
Having so many GLUT transporters is also weird. Why so many?
It turns out that that these genes originated through a process of duplication. Once upon a time there was just one GLUT transporter and that one got duplicated, so then there were two. Later on, one of the copies got duplicated so that then there were three. Different copies evolved different functions somewhat randomly.
The process is analogous to the evolution of related species except that this involves individual genes becoming separate. Scientists think the genes are related to each other as shown in this diagram.[7]
Many of these genes are very old; fish have them.[8] Being so ancient is probably why these genes are scattered randomly among our chromosomes.[9]
Conclusion
Any student trying to learn about GLUT transporters is going to be unhappy about how complex and chaotic this assortment of genes is. My best guess as to why it's so complicated is that it evolved in a trial-and-error way, long, long ago, with organisms sticking with whatever worked, thereby adding needless complexity in the process.
More to read
This article will tell you more than you want to know:
Glucose transporters in adipose tissue, liver, and skeletal muscle in metabolic health and disease - Pflügers Archiv - European Journal of Physiology
A family of facilitative glucose transporters (GLUTs) is involved in regulating tissue-specific glucose uptake and metabolism in the liver, skeletal muscle, and adipose tissue to ensure homeostatic control of blood glucose levels. Reduced glucose transport activity results in aberrant use of energy substrates and is associated with insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. It is well established that GLUT2, the main regulator of hepatic hexose flux, and GLUT4, the workhorse in insulin- and contraction-stimulated glucose uptake in skeletal muscle, are critical contributors in the control of whole-body glycemia. However, the molecular mechanism how insulin controls glucose transport across membranes and its relation to impaired glycemic control in type 2 diabetes remains not sufficiently understood. An array of circulating metabolites and hormone-like molecules and potential supplementary glucose transporters play roles in fine-tuning glucose flux between the different organs in response to an altered energy demand.

question: What is the role of a ketogenic diet in curing diabetes and thyroid diseases?
a_text:
Keto diet for Diabetics (Type-2)
The keto diet is a high-fat, low-carb diet, which limits carb intake, therefore, lowers blood sugar levels in the blood.
A ketogenic diet makes changes in your eating habits that improve the blood sugar levels tremendously. A healthy individual is recommended to consume 2000 calories with 25% carbs intake on a daily basis. So this obviously means that the keto diet is excellent for diabetics, right? The answer is not so simple.
If we are going to single out one specific group, we really need to keep their limitations in mind too. And when talking about diabetics, we need to keep ketosis in mind. Ketosis is the result of low-carb but a high fat-intake. When you take in fewer carbs, your body starts burning fats and proteins to get the required energy via ketosis. Ketosis converts both, fats as well as proteins in ketones. Ketones then drive your whole body. As far as carbs are concerned, you are taking them in less amount and so there is less amount of sugars produced as a result of carbs breaking down. Therefore, fewer spikes in blood sugar levels!
However, watching out for your ketones level is equally important. High levels of ketones can make the blood acidic. Acidic blood can damage your liver, heart, and kidneys! That’s why it’s imperative that you take account of every nutrient that you intake. This way, you can control your blood sugar level while keeping your body safe from harm of excess ketones.
Blood sugar levels are determined by hemoglobin A1C testing. People with type-2 diabetes always have more than 7% of A1C levels, whereas people living without diabetes should have A1C score around 5.7%. With a ketogenic diet, it is possible to lower the A1C score. Keto diet focuses on eating more fats and proteins. Taking fewer carbs means consuming fewer starches which in return means lower levels of sugar.

question: "Have you ever had ""diabetic rage"" (an extreme angry outburst caused by high or low blood sugar)? If so, did you remember anything about it?"
a_text:
Q: “Have you ever had “diabetic rage” (an extreme angry outburst caused by high or low blood sugar)? If so, did you remember anything about it?”
Ummmm…. before I respond, I want to change the “name”; it’s NOT NOT NOT “diabetic rage”… it’s HYPOGLYCAEMIC “rage”. Or more accurately… when hypoglycaemic, we’re subject to losing all inhibitions and become entirely dysfunctional due to the loss of various brain functions - literally. We can’t focus, we can’t form logical conclusions, and we can’t understand what’s happening… and as BG (Blood Glucose) drops into the 50s mg/dl (or thereabouts), most folks start to become impatient and belligerent. For some, it may happen at higher levels… especially those new to the experience.
For that… yes, I’ve experienced this. Many times. About a year and half ago, my wife woke me to tell me that I was low, and needed to consume some glucose… I argued with her, and insisted… I was about to strike her, but still realised that was unacceptable, so I put my fists - BOTH of them - through the wall. My left went right through, to the outer wall; my right hit a stud, and crushed the drywall in the spot I hit. By that point… my wife had a yoo-hoo box straw at my lips, and I drank it… and was fine in about 15 minutes (the stuff is essentially liquid sugar). I remember it all quite clearly. MOST of the time, I’m simply impatient… and I usually realise it right away, and treat it. BUT… when I’m sleeping, I’m not aware of it… until I’m awakened; if I’m too low, I’ll be difficult and sometimes belligerent. Another experience from lows when sleeping is to “waken” into a stuporous state… in which I’ve suddenly realised the solution to some weighty problem (like the cure to Type 1 diabetes), with visions of how to effectuate it so everyone can be rid of it… but then, I can’t find something that’s needed, or figure out where it was… or some stupid issue like that. It’s more a matter of being terribly confused and unable to sort it all out.
Hypoglycaemia is a very frustrating thing… as our BG levels drop, brain cells start dying off (at around 50 mg/dl), but more so, they’re mis-firing, and our cognitive functions are out of order… and one of the first brain regions to be affected are the temporal lobes… where the seat of “self control” resides… the part of the brain that perceives what are and what are not socially acceptable behaviours. Hence the belligerence.
Or at least, that’s my story… and I’m sticking to it… ;-)

question: Can someone with diabetes be on the keto diet for a lifetime?
a_text:
The keto diet has exploded in popularity over the last few years, largely due to the substantial weight loss benefits associated with it. Since 40% of US adults over 20 years old are estimated to be obese, weight loss has become a major goal for the majority of the population. Controlling your diet is the single biggest thing you can do, to make a positive impact on your long-term health. By developing good habits, you are setting yourself up for a lifetime of optimal health.
In reality though, 10% of the US population suffers from diabetes, which is both a crippling condition in its own right, as well as an early warning sign of worse health problems to come. Diabetes causes high blood sugar, and needs to be treated with medication, so worse problems don’t occur. Untreated diabetes can lead to organ problems, nerve issues, kidney problems, and even issues with your eyesight. Unsurprisingly, each person’s A1c level (or long-term measurement of your blood sugar levels) is highly correlated with the risk for developing diabetes. The more sugar you take in on a daily basis, the more likely you are to develop diabetes. This is why the keto diet may be a great help for diabetes – it severely limits your carbohydrate and sugar intake.
Previously a niche problem, diabetes (especially type II) exploded into a full-blown health crisis in the United States. While the ever-increasing obesity rate gets a lot of press, the truth is diabetes is one of the biggest drivers behind obesity. In fact, many cases of insulin-resistance and type II diabetes go unreported. Not only can the keto diet help to manage diabetes, it is perhaps more valuable as a preventative strategy. Actually, you can adopt a keto diet before any problems arise and avoid developing diabetes or obesity. Since type II diabetes accounts for over 95% of all diabetes cases in the United States, avoiding development of the disease is huge scientific progress. Rather than relying on costly, after-the-fact medications, you can protect your good health by simply changing your diet.
What Is A Normal Blood Sugar Range?
For those without diabetes, a normal blood sugar range is 100 mg/dL after not eating for eight hours, and less than 140 mg/dL two hours after eating. Consistent blood sugar readings that are greater than these ranges are highly problematic. Hyperglycemia is the medical term for blood sugar that is dangerously high, and if you continue to take in too much sugar on a daily basis, eventually you will develop serious problems with your blood sugar.
What Are The Dangers Of High Blood Sugar?
There are both short-term, daily consequences to high blood sugar and long-term consequences. On a daily basis, you will need to start taking insulin. On a long-term basis, however, you will have to deal with diabetes, as well as all the negative consequences that come with it. If you suffer from diabetes, you will likely have low energy, constant hunger, excessive thirst, itchy skin, and a constant need to urinate. These symptoms should help scare you straight into keeping your blood sugar low.
What Is Diabetes?
Diabetes can simply be thought of as the malfunctioning of your body, when you consume too much sugar on a regular basis. When you have good health, your body produces insulin. Your pancreas releases it when you eat, and all remains well. But if you develop diabetes, your body starts to become resistant to insulin. This becomes problematic for a number of reasons, one of which is forcing your pancreas to work too hard. This causes damage to the cells in your pancreas, and eventually your pancreas may not be able to produce any insulin at all.
Type I Diabetes
Type I diabetes is a specific type of disease related to blood sugar regulation, but importantly, it’s different than type II diabetes. Those suffering from this form of diabetes cannot produce any insulin at all, leaving them at a severe physical disadvantage. However, while type II diabetes is almost always caused by lifestyle, type I is genetic, and cannot be avoided. Sometimes type I diabetes is called juvenile diabetes, or insulin-dependent diabetes.
It’s also important to distinguish between nutritional ketosis, and diabetic ketoacidosis. In nutritional ketosis, your ketone levels are elevated, but nothing else. This allows for your body to use stored fat for energy, and also helps to lower your insulin levels. Diabetic ketoacidosis, on the other hand, elevates your blood sugar and ketone levels, putting you in a very dangerous situation. While rare, it is still important to discuss starting a keto diet with your doctor, if you have any issues with blood sugar, so you avoid diabetic ketoacidosis.
Type II Diabetes
Type II diabetes is largely different than type I, as sufferers can usually still produce insulin. They are, however, hugely insulin resistant. There are a number of risk factors for developing type II diabetes, including inactivity, obesity, and too much sugar in the diet. Over 30 million people in the United States suffer from type II diabetes, even though it is largely avoidable. This is one of the many facts which show that the American diet has gone horribly off-track, and most people need to drastically alter their eating patterns. In fact, health experts estimate that by 2030, about 50% of the population in the US will be obese. Of those, most, if not all, will be suffering from type II diabetes.

question: When people with diabetic neuropathy get feelings of cold feet, are their feet really cold or is it just their impression? Can the feet get so cold to need an amputation?
a_text:
It’s complex.
Diabetes can affect the feet in a variety of ways. The two most obvious ones are:
Damaged nerves
Damaged blood vessels
This said, last week I saw a lady whose Type I diabetes was diagnosed in the 1970s. She is meticulous in her control (now managing her new pump like a master) and her feet are still perfect. But back to those who are less fortunate.
Clearly, if you have bad vascular disease, then impaired blood flow will make your feet chilly. In the severe cases I often see in hospital, the foot is often noticeably cold.
But diabetes can be more subtle in its effects, and one of these is related to the various neuropathies that occur. This has been studied rather a lot. Early work[1] showed that those with diabetic neuropathy have impaired temperature sensation—they become fairly hopeless at detecting temperature changes, as demonstrated in the image above.
So their report of cold (or indeed warm) feet won’t be reliable.
This is likely because it’s the small fibres that transmit temperature sensation, and these are more affected in diabetes. Interestingly, more recent work has shown that the feet of those with diabetic neuropathy are often warmer:
Correlation between Plantar Foot Temperature and Diabetic Neuropathy: A Case Study by Using an Infrared Thermal Imaging Technique
Diabetic neuropathy consists of multiple clinical manifestations of which loss of sensation is most prominent. High temperatures under the foot coupled with reduced or complete loss of sensation can predispose the patient to foot ulceration. The aim of ...
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3005049/
This may well be because the small sympathetic fibres that normally constrict peripheral blood vessels are also impaired. The paper is worth a read—if only for the pretty pictures :)
Of course, dilated vessels won’t warm things up if the darn blood vessels are blocked,* but as I said at the start, it’s complex.
Everyone with diabetes should of course take meticulous care of their feet, as the tiniest lesion can lead to loss of a limb.
Especially if you have neuropathy.
My 2c, Dr Jo.
*And an impaired autoregulatory
response is never a good thing, as it robs you of your reserve.
Footnotes
[1] https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007%2FBF00273859.pdf

question: Why does exercise not lower my blood sugar levels?
a_text:
Q: “Why does exercise not lower my blood sugar levels?”
It does reduce your glucose levels; but you’re likely not testing WHERE it does - and the FIRST thing that exercise does is RAISE your BG (Blood Glucose - the proper term for “blood sugar”) level.
Your ENTIRE BODY is loaded with Glucose; not “just” your blood, but your tissues and interstitial spaces (spaces between tissues) contain glucose; it is there for a reason - TO FUEL EVERY CELL OF YOUR BODY.
Every living cell MUST perform a function called cellular respiration; this is the process by which the cells generate the energy for life. They take in glucose and oxygen, oxidize (burn) the glucose (C6H12O6) in the oxygen (O2), thereby generating energy to live on, and cast off wastes (primarily carbon dioxide - CO2 - and water - H2O).
When you initiate activity - you stimulate what is known as the “fight or flight” response. Now, you probably think of this as a threat response, and it is; but actually, it goes on ALL THE TIME - whenever you are active. Your liver stores glucose (in a denser, more stable form called glycogen), and when you begin to wake up - it releases it into the bloodstream as glucose again to “prime the pump” so you can hunt down and prepare breakfast… or, nowadays, stumble to the ‘fridge and the coffeepot. ANY time you begin an activity, your liver pumps glucose into your bloodstream.
BUT… that means you ARE reducing your overall body’s glucose levels; but it’s being “transferred” out of the liver and long muscles, which also store it as glycogen. When long muscles are active, they use THIS glycogen preferentially over your BG - until the long-muscle stores are depleted, THEN you begin “burning” BG.
If the exercise session is short - your BG likely won’t reduce noticeably; it will initially rise, then begin to drop to your normal resting level; but if you don’t stay at it, it will not drop very much. BUT… you HAVE “burned off” lots of stored glucose.
The BETTER reason for regular exercise vis-a-vis BG levels is IMPROVED CELLULAR RESPONSE TO INSULIN. T2 (Type 2 DM - Diabetes Mellitus) is a disease of insulin resistance; the cells resist the primary action of insulin - which is to facilitate the transfer of glucose OUT of the bloodstream and into the cells; some cells don’t need insulin to take up glucose - but most do. So when cells resist that transfer… too much glucose gets “left behind” in the bloodstream - and the cells don’t get the fuel they need as fast as they need it. This results in chronic fatigue, and for many, a sedentary lifestyle.
BUT… if you exercise regularly (at least 4 or 5 days a week, never more than 2 days “off” in a row, and at least 35 or 30 minutes per day - more is better), your body’s cells will become more insulin-receptive ALL THE TIME; this is why T2s (Type 2 DM patients) are advised to get regular exercise. What you’re doing is less important than getting out and doing it; regular exercise of 150 minutes per week, spread over at least 4 days, DOES improve cellular response to insulin - ALL THE TIME.
Here’s a useful page on the subject from the endocrinologists (the docs that specialise in treating all types of “diabetes”):
https://www.endocrineweb.com/conditions/type-2-diabetes/type-2-diabetes-exercise
I hope you found this helpful; and keep exercising!

question: Why do so many bread recipes tell you to add sugar? What if you're diabetic or simply prefer a more savory flavor?
a_text:
Normally the amount of sugar added to the water and yeast at the beginning of the mix is very small and only there to feed the yeast, not actually sweeten the dough. There are sweet breads out there, but most are not intended to be sweet after they’ve mixed. The sugar is merely a food for the yeast.
There are many breads that use an autolyse method instead. It’s a mix of water and flour followed by a rest period of 30 minutes to an hour. Because it allows a portion of the flour to become saturated and allows the gluten strands to become stronger, it can help with the dough becoming more elastic, the crust looking better and having a better crisp, and there’ll be more flavor development hopefully. No sugar needed at all.
Starters are another way to avoid using any sugar. A pre-ferment or chef’s starter is a reserve of the previous day’s dough, yeast and all, that’s been left to retard overnight in the walk-in. At home, it would be a much smaller portion. This won’t be enough to make it taste like a sourdough, but it will give a loaf a great rise and there will be a much better flavor to your bread.
Sourdough starters are of course wonderful ways of getting great flavors in your breads as well as beautiful crusts and those glorious elastic breads. No sugar needed.
The addition of sugar to breads is actually fairly recent. It became popular in the 1900’s as bread production on a large scale started. Breads needed to be produced quickly and neighborhood bakeries were hard pressed to keep up with factories making sliced bread for grocery stores popping up everywhere. Sugar added to the water and yeast helped to make the production of what we now call “artisan breads” go faster.
If you enjoy making bread that isn’t made in a bread machine, there are many recipes that don’t have sugar in them. It doesn’t even require extensive research.

question: What are the long-term effects of type 2 diabetes?
a_text:
Q: “What are the long-term effects of type 2 diabetes?”
I PRESUME you mean type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2). Be aware - there are THREE types of DM (Diabetes Melltius), and FOUR types of DI (Diabetes Insipidus). But T2 DM is the most common.
DI and DM are COMPLETELY DIFFERENT groups of diseases; DI diseases involve a lack of, or poor storage of, or poor response to the hormone vasopressin, the fluid-balance regulating hormone. DM diseases involve a lack of, or poor response to, the BG (Blood Glucose) regulating hormone insulin.
The long-term effects of T2 are IDENTICAL to the long-term effects of ALL THREE DM diseases (autoimmune T1, and pancreatogenic T3c are the other two types of DM).
The long-term effects range from NONE AT ALL, to TOTAL ORGAN DESTRUCTION AND FAILURE. Where a patient falls on that spectrum depends ENTIRELY on how well they control their BG levels. Here’s a little outline I wrote for a similar query.
“Diabetes Mellitus Complications outline
DM refers to one of THREE COMPLETELY DIFFERENT DISEASES (each with sub-types) that cause elevated BG (Blood Glucose) levels; if those levels are allowed to remain elevated too high and for too long, THAT in turn causes SEVERE DAMAGE to the body’s vasculature and organs, which causes all the nasty “complications” that DM is known for - and this applies to ALL THREE types of DM. It’s the elevated BG that causes “complications”, and that happens in all of them.
The first and most noticeable damages are to the blood vessels and nerves; these add to the damage, and lead to damage to EVERY TISSUE IN THE BODY.
To start… when BG is elevated, excess AGES are created - Advanced Glycation End productS. These AGES are created when the haemoglobin glycates - which means binds chemically to portions of the glucose molecules in the bloodstream. AGES are a sort of by-product of that process. AGES are a sticky-sweet “gunk” that build up in the bloodstream, but as they are distributed throughout the body, they adhere to, smother, and kill the cells of the tissue they come into contact with - which is EVERY cell of the body, ultimately; here’s an article focused on the vasculature: The Role of Advanced Glycation End Products in Diabetic Vascular Complications
AND… when BG is elevated, endothelial cells’ glucose metabolism is increased, and the enzyme hexokinase 2 (HK2) degrades more slowly, leading to endothelial cell dysfunction.. and problems: How Does Hyperglycemia Cause Damage And What Can We Do To Avoid It?
SO… those are the underlying biochemical issues; here’s a little intro to the “complications” of DM - which are ALL caused by elevated BG; this one outlines HOW MUCH those complications occur: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/gap/cgi-bin/GetPdf.cgi?id=phd000390
Hypertension is among the first “complications” to appear; the immediate damage to the vasculature causes elevated BP (Blood Pressure), which is hypertension if it becomes prolonged. This, in turn. leads to CVD and heart problems, often resulting in heart disease and failure.
Meanwhile, neuropathies (there are seven types of neuropathy) will cause damage to the nerves; peripheral neuropathy is the most common of these, but by no means the most damaging. ALL nerves are subject to neuropathy (nerve damage), and when damaged - your body is unaware of injury or issues, and you can lose muscle control, as well as autonomic functions (digestion and so on). Most folks focus on peripheral neuropathy, which can cause loss of feeling in the limbs (feet-toes/hands-fingers), leading to infections, gangrene and amputations; but you can also lose the ability to digest foods, vision may become impaired, sexual function may be impaired (in both men and women), muscles may fail, skin may become dry and flaky, and hair may fall out - and these are just some of the issues caused by the different types of neuropathy.
Nephropathy is another major issue for DM patients - this is damage to the nephrons of the kidneys. This, in turn, causes CKD - Chronic Kidney Disease, and ultimately, renal failure; this is why so many diabetics need dialysis.
And the lists go on… elevated BG levels are BAD… and cause damage to ALL of the body’s tissues and organs. This is why good BG control is so important to us.”

question: How do I decipher all of the information concerning Type 2 diabetes? I was just diagnosed last week. I am leaning towards a plant based diet and intermittent fasting, does that sound right?
a_text:
Q: “How do I decipher all of the information concerning Type 2 diabetes? I was just diagnosed last week. I am leaning towards a plant based diet and intermittent fasting, does that sound right?”
No, that sounds dead wrong… literally. There are REAL science-based guidelines available to manage T2 (Type 2 DM - Diabetes Mellitus). Fads are NOT a good idea.
Rather than a “plant based” diet - learn to count and control carb intake. Rather than fasting - get REGULAR exercise of AT LEAST 150 minutes per week, with no more than 2 days “off” during the week.
Following is an outline of T2, with several excellent links and resources that will help you learn how to manage YOUR T2 - and KNOW THIS: each patient is DIFFERENT; what “works” for one will NOT work for another; we’re each a unique biochemical machine, and must tailor our treatment to our circumstances and biochemical response to foods, activity, and meds.
Here’s a little T2 Primer:
“T2 is an hereditary disease (meaning it's not only genetic, but often transferred from one generation to the next - though that's not a "requirement") caused by a certain combination of genetic alleles that cause a biochemical problem called IR - Insulin Resistance. In short - although your pancreas produces all the insulin you should need - your body's cells don't respond to it efficiently. Insulin's job is to transfer glucose (a simple form of sugar, and the only kind your body can use to fuel its cells) from the bloodstream (your body's "delivery system") into those cells. When the cells resist insulin's action - they don't get the fuel they need, and too much sugar gets "left behind" in your bloodstream - leading to the first and primary symptom, elevated BG (Blood Glucose). Elevated BG leads to the typical early symptoms of polydipsia (excessive thirst), polyurea (frequent urination), fatigue, polyphagia (prolonged hunger), blurry vision, and easy weight gain. Most T2s have elevated BG for a while before the symptoms are severe enough to go to the doc and get it dx'd (diagnosed).
In response to the cellular IR - your pancreas starts overproducing insulin. At first - this works, and your BG stays in "normal" range (about 90 to 120 mg/dl all day long, with 80% of the day spent below 100 mg/dl). BUT... in time, your pancreas can no longer make enough "extra" insulin, and BG levels climb - and that's when folks get dx'd. But in all likelihood - your pancreas is still producing "more than normal" amounts of insulin - but the cellular resistance to it is too much, and that's why your BG is still too high.
This is where the "lifestyle changes" come in. For a long time, docs have been blaming T2s for giving themselves the disease by overeating and not getting enough exercise. THAT is a LIE. You don't get the disease without the genetic markers....and there are lots of overweight lazy people that do NOT have T2. There are over 80 genetic anomalies associated with T2, but there are so far THREE that are absolutely confirmed as causative. All three are located near IRS1 (Insulin Receptor Substrate 1) on chromosome 2 of the human genome; these are SNPs (Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms) rs2943650, rs2943634, and rs2972146. These all cause the underlying biochemical issue of IR… but also, they pre-dispose the carrier to a tendency to gain weight easily, and fatigue readily.
By eating a proper diet and getting regular physical activity, you CAN improve (for some, even "normalise") your BG levels. Here's why.
The glucose in your bloodstream comes primarily from the carbohydrates you eat. When talking about a "proper" diet - we're talking about limiting carbs to a level your body can handle. The less glucose there is in your bloodstream, the better your body can transfer it to the cells. HOW MUCH to limit carbs is DIFFERENT FOR EVERYONE - which is why there are so many different approaches to meal planning for T2s. The "trick" is to learn what works for you. A gentleman named Alan Shanley has an excellent website that covers everything you need to know about this... and the primary thing you need to start is learning to count carbs, and testing your BG regularly to learn how many carbs your system can tolerate at each meal. So I'm going to give you some links to pages you should read on these subjects:
Carb counting for beginners: https://www.bd.com/resource.aspx?IDX=9829
Carbs by foods: http://www.med.umich.edu/1libr/MEND/CarbList.pdf
If your doc hasn't suggested a meter - ask for a script so you can get one through your insurance, or just go to any major pharmacy and get one of their own brand; Walmart has them for about $10 (the meter will last for several years, with a few battery changes), with strips (you need a new strip for each test) for 18 cents apiece. Docs often don't think T2's need meters - but you DO. Without testing, you have no idea what your meals and exercise are doing to your BG levels.
CGMs (Continuous Glucose Monitors) are an alternate way of following your BG levels; these devices measure interstitial fluid - constantly. they are a “lag indicator” of BG - but reliable for following your BG fluctuations, and a wealth of information; but they are less readily available to T2s due to insurance limitations.
Here are some important resources:
From Alan's site:
Getting Started: Getting Started
Testing with purpose (use your meter to control BG): Test, Review, Adjust
Target BG levels: Blood Glucose Targets
So... that covers most of the dietary issues - on to 'exercise". The reason exercise (by which we mean ANY form of regular physical activity) is important is that active cells are insulin-receptive cells. Meaning when you get regular physical activity (running, walking, swimming, bicycling - ANYTHING you enjoy and can stick to) at least 4 or 5 days a week for at least 35 or 30 minutes each day, you are improving your body's cellular response to insulin - making the insulin your body is already making more effective. If you aren't accustomed to regular activity - start with something you like for short durations, and work up over time. It's very beneficial. You'll also read about exercise lowering BG by "burning off" the glucose - which it does... BUT... that's only for as long as you're exercising. The REAL benefit is from the improvement in your cellular response to insulin, which, once you're getting in regular activity, remains all the time - NOT just when you're being active. Here’s a useful page from the endocrinology website (endocrinologists are the docs that specialize in treating diabetics): Type 2 Diabetes and Exercise
Another excellent site on all types of DM – here’s the page on T2: Type 2 Diabetes :: Diabetes Education Online
On T2 medications - KNOW THIS - all T2 oral meds REQUIRE the use of "diet and exercise" to be effective (read the fine print in the paperwork that comes with it). The standard starting T2 med is met, or metformin. This med does NOT actually lower BG - what it does is inhibit your body from raising your BG, which is a normal part of the glucose balance system that keeps non-D's (non-Diabetic's) BG in the 90 to 120 mg/dl range. By dulling this side of the body's response - the met is keeping your BG from getting too high too often. It's the "diet and exercise" that control the glucose you get from eating. Also - for many people, met needs to be taken for a couple of weeks before it starts having an effect on BG. Met also slows absorption of glucose from the foods you eat (a bit), and improves cellular response to insulin - a TINY bit.
Why is keeping BG as close to "normal" as possible important? Because elevated BG levels are what cause all the nasty complications of D - vascular damage leading to CVD and atherosclerosis, and retinopathy leading to blindness, and nephropathy leading to kidney failure, nerve damage leading to neuropathy and loss of limbs, and so on. BUT... it's not the high BG alone that does this - high BG leads to high HbA1c levels - you may have had a test referred to as an A1c test; this is a measure of the percentage of your haemoglobin that has glycated, which means bound chemically to the sugar in your blood (glucose). When that chemical binding happens - AGES are created (Advanced Glycation End productS), and it's ultimately these AGES that do the damage - they're a sticky-sweet "gunk" that adheres to, covers and smothers the tissue of the vasculature and organs, slowly killing them off (leading to the various "complications" along the way). A non-diabetic's HbA1c level ranges from 3.5% to 5.5%. The most extensive study of complications in diabetics (DCCT/EDIC studies) found that those that maintain an HbA1c level of NO MORE than 6.5% suffer the least amount of these "complications". For every point above 5.5%, the risk for those complications goes up about 30% (NIH ADVANCE collaborative group).
Besides AGES, there is also a chemical reaction to elevated BG in the endothelial cells; this also contributes to the malfunctioning of those cells, and the damage that leads to complications… especially vascular degradation.
Finally, for those with “pre-diabetes”… here’s a good intro from NIH on how to prevent the onset of full-blown T2, geared to those with high risk factors for it - and those with “pre-diabetes” (a condition akin to being “a little bit pregnant”):
Preventing Type 2 Diabetes | NIDDK
Learn how you can prevent type 2 diabetes, such as losing weight by being active and eating low-calorie, low-fat foods, or taking the diabetes drug metformin.
https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/preventing-type-2-diabetes
Another site on prevention, from the ADA:
Risk Test | ADA
American Diabetes Association 2451 Crystal Drive, Suite 900 Arlington, VA 22202 For donations by mail: P.O. Box 7023 Merrifield, VA  22116-7023 1-800-DIABETES ( 800-342-2383 )
https://www.diabetes.org/risk-test
Another from Mayo Clinic:
Diabetes prevention: 5 tips for taking control
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/type-2-diabetes/in-depth/diabetes-prevention/art-20047639
A final one from the endocrinologists:
https://www.endocrineweb.com/conditions/type-2-diabetes/type-2-diabetes-prevention
So… that’s a brief outline of T2 and pre-diabetes; I hope you find it helpful. Good Luck!!

question: What are the types of diabetes and what causes diabetes?
a_text:
Type 1 diabetes is where your pancreas fails to produce enough insulin, as a result of the Islets of Langerhans (which produce the insulin) being attacked by your own immune system.
Type 2 diabetes is where you produce enough insulin but your body doesn’t respond to it properly, called insulin resistance.
Type 3 diabetes has been proposed as a label for a type of insulin resistance linked with Alzheimer’s.
Type 3c pancreatogenic diabetes is lack of insulin due to damage to the pancreas, such as from injury, infection or cancer.
Gestational diabetes is temporary Type 2-style insulin resistance due to pregnancy.
Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY) is a set of four different genetic conditions which can manifest after puberty - at least one reduces the amount of insulin produced, and one screws up the body’s ability to assess its own blood sugar levels.
Neonatal diabetes is where you’re just born with a pancreas that inherently doesn’t make enough insulin.
Wolfram syndrome is a genetic disorder which among other things produces similar symptoms to Type 1 (low insulin, frequent urination).
Alström syndrome is a genetic disorder which among other things produces similar symptoms to Type 2 (insulin resistance).
Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA) produces a combination of Type 1 and Type 2.
Steroid-induced diabetes is high blood sugar and insulin resistance brought on by steroid abuse.
Cystic fibrosis diabetes is a combination of Type 1 and Type 2 but with different underlying causes.

question: When people say that type 2 diabetes is progressive and gets worse over time, what sort of (worsening) progressive do they mean, and what kind of timeline do They mean?
a_text:
Q: “When people say that type 2 diabetes is progressive and gets worse over time, what sort of (worsening) progressive do they mean, and what kind of timeline do They mean?”
“They” mean MANY DIFFERENT THINGS, as is clear from the answers already offered; don’t waste time beyond Luis Doriocourt’s good answer.
RESEARCHERS and clinicians refer to T2 (Type 2 DM - Diabetes Mellitus) as “progressive”; but ALL they mean by that, is that the underlying cause of the disease - cellular resistance to insulin’s action - INCREASES over time; how much, and how fast, VARIES - A LOT - from patient to patient. THIS HAS NOTHING TO DO with “getting worse”, or developing “complications”, or anything like that; it is PURELY a biological fact that as the pancreatic endocrine beta cells wear out, and cellular resistance to insulin increases, the disease “progresses” - along the aetiological lines that are WELL ESTABLISHED as the disease progression.
Over time, BG (Blood Glucose) levels increase because the insulin doesn’t work as it should, and vasculature (the blood vessel system) deteriorates - primarily seen in hardening of the arteries (atherosclerosis) evidenced by hypertension (increased blood pressure). Many other problems may develop - and ALL are related to the elevated BG levels; but that is NOT what is meant by the “progressive” nature of the disease.
The disease is GENETIC - without the genetic markers, you don’t develop it. BUT… even WITH the genetic markers - you do NOT have to develop it - or let it “progress”. A carb-limited diet, and regular daily exercise, WILL slow the progression - and if begun early enough, can prevent it from developing at all.
Cellular resistance to insulin means that the glucose your cells need doesn’t get into them as fast or as completely as it should. That means too much glucose is “left behind” in your bloodstream - and THAT is what causes all the nasty “complications” of DM.
The PRIMARY means of improving cellular response to insulin is EXERCISE; you’ll hear people say that exercise lowers BG by “burning off” the glucose, and it does - but the PRIMARY benefit of REGULAR exercise is that it makes the body’s cells MORE RECEPTIVE to insulin - and NOT “just” when you’re active; if you exercise REGULARLY (at least 5 days a week, at least 30 minutes a day - more is better) your cellular sensitivity to insulin remains with you ALL THE TIME - even if you’re not exercising. And THAT is the BEST way to STOP the progression of the disease. ): httphttp://s://www.endocrineweb.com/conditions/type-2-diabetes/type-2-diabetes-exercise
By limiting carbs - you put less stress on the insulin-producing pancreatic endocrine beta cells, thereby sparing them the need to constantly over-produce insulin - and thereby helping them function longer and more efficiently. Combined with regular exercise - this is a MAJOR improvement in BG control, and if begun early, it can forestall progression from “pre-diabetes” to full-blown diabetes, and if one is a full-blown diabetic - it will slow the ongoing progression. MANY T2s manage their BG with “only” diet (carb limitation) and exercise (a REGULAR regimen).
Here’s some links to pages on forestalling the progression from pre- to -diabetic.
Here’s a good intro from NIH on how to prevent the onset of full-blown T2, geared to those with high risk factors for it - and those with “pre-diabetes” (a condition akin to being “a little bit pregnant”): Preventing Type 2 Diabetes | NIDDK

question: Why does glucometer reading is high compared to lab test reading?
a_text:
Glucometer is a simple screwing test but has less accuracy than a lab blood sugar with a variation of as much as 20 percent.
In glucometer “whole capillary blood” is tested meaning that the blood contains particles like red cells and plasma (liquid). On the other hand in lab test the blood drawn is from vein (intrinsically less sugar since sugar is extracted by the tissues), seep rated from red cells by centrifugal ion and then tested.
Glucometer is a convenient screening test, but keep a track by testing long term glucose parameters by “Hb A1c” levels.

question: Is type 2 diabetes predominantly self-inflicted?
a_text:
NO. That’s out-dated thinking, based on out-dated science. In the past decade, research into the human genome has demonstrated that you don’t get T2 (Type 2 diabetes mellitus) UNLESS you have the genetic markers for it; BUT… having the genetic markers does NOT mean you MUST get it.
Having said that… certain behaviours that are often considered to be the “cause” of T2 MAY accelerate its onset and/or worsen its severity. The genetics behind T2 are very complex - it’s not one rare anomaly - it’s actually several configurations of very common alleles, which, if arranged in certain orders, will induce T2. What that means, biochemically, is a cellular resistance to the action of insulin.
Insulin’s job is to facilitate the transfer of glucose from the bloodstream (the body’s delivery and waste removal system) into the cells - which NEED it for fuel. When those cells resist that transfer - too much glucose gets “left behind” in the bloodstream, and too little gets into the cells.
In an effort to overcome that resistance - the body produces MORE insulin - and that works… for a while, until it doesn’t. T2 is a “progressive” disease - meaning, the insulin resistance of the cells increases all the time, and eventually, the body can’t produce enough “extra” insulin to overcome the cellular resistance - and that’s when the symptoms start.
IF a person is overweight - that will mean MORE insulin is needed; insulin need STARTS with total weight - every cell must have insulin, so the more you weigh, the more insulin you need. BUT… the same alleles that cause insulin resistance ALSO cause obesity - so in fact, being overweight is a SYMPTOM of T2 - NOT the cause. The other two factors oft cited as “causes” are over-consumption of carbohydrates, and a sedentary lifestyle. BUT… as T2 develops, people feel hungry longer than they “should”, because the cells aren’t getting the benefit of the glucose the patient is producing… AND… T2 itself causes fatigue - leading the patient to engage in a more sedentary lifestyle.
As the disease progresses, the constant state of hyperinsulinemia (the body is always awash in insulin) causes degradation and loss of endocrine beta cell mass and functionality - leading the long-term T2 to lose insulin production capacity; it is in this phase that T2s may start to need insulin like T1s.
Also… there are lots of obese folks that do NOT have T2 - and THAT is because there’s a T2 allele that PROTECTS against T2 - but causes obesity.
For more in-depth reading on the topic - here’s some sources:
“Genetic Variant Near IRS1 Is Associated with Type 2 diabetes, Insulin Resistance, and Hyperinsulinemia”, Nature Genetics, 2009
“Genetic Variation Near IRS1 Associated with Adiposity and a Favourable Metabolic Profile”, Kilpelainen et al, Nature Genetics, 2011
“New Genes Hold Clue to Why Many With Obesity Don’t Get Diabetes”, Becky McCall, Medscape 3/19/18
“The Genetic Architecture of Type 2 Diabetes”, Fuchsberger, et al. Nature. July 11, 2016.

question: What are the best medications for type 2 diabetes with little side effects?
a_text:
Hi,
I understand where you’re coming from. If I had diabetes, I would want the “bestest” drug out there too.
To begin we will need to define what “best” mean. To me, it would be something with the highest efficacy, safest track record and if possible, won’t cost a bomb.

That is why we don’t just hit everybody with metformin. How good if it were that simple! This is also why we have medical guidelines setup by international experts, to aid in choosing the best treatment for each individual patient.
Your doctor is always the best person to help you decide which treatment is most suitable for you, as treatment options need to be individualised. If for some reason you have doubt on what your doctor has told you, the best thing is to seek a second opinion from another qualified doctor.
The WORST thing you can do is to start hunting for miracle treatments, because you will inevitably end up in the various traps set by unscrupulous businessmen trying to earn a quick buck. People with chronic diseases will always be their number one target, as EVERYBODY wants a quick fix.
