question: Why do people with diabetes need maltodextrin in their food?
a_text:
Q: “Why do people with diabetes need maltodextrin in their food?”
We do NOT “need” maltodextrin in our food; as a matter of fact, it’s a simple carbohydrate - a polysaccharide, or sugar - something that many of us avoid or limit in our diets in order to control BG (Blood Glucose) levels.
Maltodextrin is a food additive; it’s used to preserve foods, and as a thickener to increase the volume of a food; it’s only found in processed foods.
Maltodextrin and table sugar (sucrose) both contain about 4 calories per gram. And it’s absorbed quickly - so it’s a high-glycaemic index food. But it’s used in very small quantities - so usually doesn’t add much in terms of carbs or calories to a given food product. And of course, when reading a food label - you won’t see the “contribution” to carbs, calories and sugars for the maltodextrin itself; it’s simply included in the overall nutritional information for the food. So… if you’re reading the food label on a Jello pudding container (a product that uses maltodextrin), the carbs and calories listed already account for the “contribution” from maltodextrin.
Diabetes Mellitus patients should generally avoid - or at least limit - their consumption of all sugars, and count the carbs in meals and limit consumption of carbs to the amount one can personally tolerate, or which one has dosed for (with insulin).
But in no event do we “need” maltodextrin in our food.

question: Why is there such a large range for pre-diabetes from 100 to 125? Why does a blood glucose of 105 indicate prediabetes? Where do they even come up with such low numbers for being prediabetic?
a_text:
I have been working on an updated edition of my book, The Thin Prediabetic
, so here is an excerpt answering the question:
The World Health Organization (WHO) hasn’t seen eye-to-eye with the American Diabetes Association for a very long time. In 1979, the National Diabetes Data Group formally created prediabetes as a diagnostic category. Prediabetes is meant to identify those at high risk for developing future Type 2 Diabetes (T2DM). Eighteen years later, in 1997, the American Diabetes Association revised its criteria for the diagnosis of T2DM and high-risk individuals and created a new category called “impaired fasting glucose”, (IFG). IFG identified as “Prediabetic,” those whose fasting plasma glucose (FPG) was high.
Classifying “Prediabetic,” those with a FPG of 100–125mg/dl, (5.6–7.8mmol), was thought to save time and resources. Instead of performing the more time-consuming (2 to 3 hour) and expensive oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), a single FPG was conceived as a test which could identify those at high-risk for developing T2DM. Never mind that the FBG varies for a multitude of reasons which we will cover shortly. (Ex. Don’t get tested after a bout of insomnia.)
Later in 2003 the ADA lowered their fasting blood glucose diagnostic threshold for prediabetes from 110 mg/dL to 100 mg/dL. Unbudgingly, the WHO has steadfastly kept the original 110 mg/dL cutoff. That 10 mg/dL difference makes a huge difference in the number labeled prediabetic.
The ADA’s lower FBG threshold means that many more people will fall into the prediabetes category. While capturing more prediabetics, the lower threshold misidentifies a larger number as at risk for diabetes, when they weren’t.
The most clearly mislabeled group are those with high FBG, normal two hour GTT values and low insulin resistance, typically middle-aged athletes.

question: Can an intestinal worm cure diabetes type II?
a_text:
I guess theoretically, it should be possible with a GM-intestinal worms. I have no idea if we're at the point where we can genetically modify parasites to make them consume only sugar and not reproduce.
However, I would be wary of any such treatment, for 2 reasons.
Intestinal worms don't only steal nutrients. They also attach themselves to the intestinal wall, and some might mess around with the tissue there by releasing chemicals. They're not just thieves. I'm sure it's relatively easy to "switch off" the chemical releasing, but getting the claws off will likely be hard using genetic engineering, since such morphological features are either formed by genes that have functions elsewhere, so you can't just knock them out. And without the claws, they can't attach themselves to the intestinal wall; I guess if they're sterilised (which they must be in any medical use), then it's relatively okay (I doubt that they can cause haemorrhaging).
Evolution. It isn't predictable, and it's unstoppable, no matter how much GM you do. Say you have a population of worms, all thriving on this sugar diet. Natural selection dictates that if they're thriving, they won't change diet. After reproduction time, an individual arises with a mutation that allows it to also eat flesh. Extreme example, but you get my point :) There is no way you can control for that, unless you stop them from reproducing. Which would mean two things: the patient must always get new worms implanted every xx days (depending on the lifespan of the worm), and that the same stock colony of worms must be kept in a lab, reproducing by cloning, and each different genotype produced during reproduction (since there are never, ever any perfect clones) must be tested for possible adverse effects as a matter of principle and probably of law. I can't imagine this would be cheap for either patient or drug company.

question: Why is type I diabetes considered an autoimmune disease but not type II?
a_text:
The problem with ‘Diabetes Mellitus' is that it is easy to assume the different versions of it are related.
They're not.
Or rather, the only place they are similar is in the symptoms. And, back in the days before we knew much about anatomy, physiology, genetics and biochemistry and their links to disease pathology we only really knew about the observed symptoms.
So, Diabetes Mellitus. The Greek of the name can be translated as ‘Fountain of Honey' and it was a poetic way of describing the excessive, sweet flavoured urine that patients produced. Ancient scholars like Areteus of Cappadocia noted this symptom and applied the name without realising that there were multiple diseases with similar symptoms.
It was only later, in the Middle Ages, that some Arabic physicians noted the different types and it's not clear if they observed this themselves or were reporting older observations that had been lost to history. They identified ‘old, fat' Diabetes and ‘young, thin' Diabetes. The basis of the more modern type 2 and 1 classification. But even they didn't understand the reasons.
As time went on, we began to understand the differences on pathology. We also started (by the 1980s) to realise that some type 2s can be young and some type 1s can develop old and being overweight isn't necessary to get type 2. This was the point where we ditched the older ‘IDDM’ and ‘NIDDM' terms and things like ‘Juvenile onset’ and ‘Maturity onset' in favour of the less confusing type 1 and type 2. This mainly driven by the realisation that terms like ‘Marurity Onset Diabetes of the Young’ were just stupid.
So, it's now clear that type 1 and type 2 are actually completely different disorders with different risk factors and pathology. Had they been discovered and identified today they would more likely be noted differently based on that pathology.
e.g. Autoimmune Pancreatic Deficiency Disorder (Type 1)
Progressive Insulin Resistance Syndrome (type 2) but only because we can then call it PIRS.
But we're stuck with the Fountain of Honey because the dude who named it had no idea how the endocrine and immune systems worked and was weirdly obsessed with tasting his patients’ wee. Which I think gets you struck off these days.

question: How do certain foods help lower the risk of diabetes?
a_text:
Most diabetics know to avoid sugar. It only makes sense: if your blood sugar is too high you shouldn't complicate the situation by ingesting more of the same.
But sugar in your diet is not the only food that will raise your blood glucose. Carbohydrates and alcohol raise your blood sugar (blood glucose level) about as quickly as eating sugar straight from the bowl. Proteins and fat are converted into energy for the body as well but don't raise the blood sugar nearly as much nor nearly as quickly.
Of course, sugar in the blood is not exactly the same as sugar in your food. The human body uses glucose as its energy source. Table sugar is sucrose, fruit sugar is fructose, and milk sugar is lactose. There are other sugars as well, but basically these sugars are converted to glucose in the human body.
Not everyone has a sweet tooth, but I certainly do. It goes without saying (but I'll say it anyway) that diabetics should avoid eating anything made with sugar or high-fructose corn syrup including: candy, cake, cookies, ice cream, donuts, marshmallow cream, circus peanuts, soda pop, Kool-aid, sports drinks, sweet tea or fruit drinks, hot chocolate, caramel corn, candy corn, jello, pudding, Popsicles, sherbet, syrup, whipped cream, pie, Cracker Barrel chocolate cake, custard, jelly, Nutella, milkshakes, Captain Crunch, etc. If I missed your favorite, add it to the list.
The following 10 foods should be avoided as well.
1. White bread. The processed flour turns to glucose almost as quickly as sugar itself. In fact, white bread is rated the same as glucose on the glycemic index. The glycemic index is a ranking according to how quickly a particular food raises blood glucose levels. High is bad, low is good. Both glucose and white bread are rated 100. Stone-ground whole wheat bread and pumpernickel bread have a much lower glycemic index.
2. White bagels. They look a lot like white bread, don't they? The yummy bagels are much higher in calories than regular bread, too. Two slices of bread equals about 150 calories whereas a good-sized bagel is twice that. Not that you can't eat bagels, but get a whole-grain variety and remember that eating a big bagel is like eating 4 slices of toast.
3. Saltine crackers. If you were the baker, you'd notice that white bread, white bagels, and crackers all start off with white flour. The same is true of standard pretzels. Whole grain crackers and pretzels are better for diabetics and non-diabetics alike.
4. White potatoes. Strangely, sweet potatoes have a lower glyemic index and raise the blood sugar less than white potatoes do.
5. White rice. Are you noticing a pattern here? Some diabetic patients choose to avoid anything white.
6. Most breakfast cereal. Unless it's made with whole grains, breakfast cereal, too, will be processed like sugar. Even quick oatmeal raises blood sugar. Stone-cut oatmeal is much better for you and is now available in standard grocery stores, right next to the "regular" oatmeal. However, the stone-cut variety takes much longer to cook, easily half an hour or more to soften the grain to the consistency of regular oatmeal.
7. Instant pasta or macaroni mixes. Almost anything "instant" or processed breaks down into sugar more quickly than the natural forms.
8. Popcorn. Yes, another white item - however, amount is the key. A cup of popcorn (unbuttered) won't raise your blood sugar much whereas eating a large theater popcorn is like eating a few candy bars.
9. Sweet fruits. The especially sweet fruits like watermelon and pineapple contain more fruit-sugar than the less sweet fruits, but again, amount is the key. A few bites won't hurt you.
10. Alcohol. Not only does it elevate your blood sugar, but it may impair your judgment regarding your diabetes. Best to avoid this altogether.

question: "Why do diabetics get diarrhea? Is there such a thing as ""diabetic diarrhea""? How is it treated?"
a_text:
How does diarrhea affect people with diabetes? If you have diabetes, you may experience diarrhea when you eat certain foods or when your blood sugar is too high or too low. When you have diabetic diarrhea, there’s more to it than the uncomfortable feeling and embarrassing moments in public restrooms. Diabetic diarrhea can lead to dehydration and malnutrition, which can be life-threatening if left untreated. That’s why it’s important to understand what causes diabetic diarrhea, as well as how to treat it with the help of your doctor.
What Causes Diabetic Diarrhea?
To understand what causes diabetic diarrhea, we need to understand how diabetes works. Diabetes affects nearly one in every 20 Americans. It’s a disease where your body either doesn’t produce enough insulin or can’t use its own insulin correctly. Without insulin, your body can’t convert food into energy—so you have really bad blood sugar control that leads to chronic high blood sugar and all sorts of nasty complications.
Are Laxatives Safe For Diabetics?
While there is no cure for diabetes, treatment can help control blood sugar levels. This can prevent some of the symptoms and complications of diabetes, such as blurred vision, infections, and impotence. Treatment may include medication (injections or pills), diet changes, and exercise. Laxatives are not prescribed for treating constipation in most people with diabetes because they make it harder to control blood sugar levels.
Can I Treat Myself or My Child Without Medical Help?
If you have diabetes, it's essential to learn how to treat minor diarrhea. Ask your doctor if there are any prescription or over-the-counter medications that might help you. If these remedies don't work, be sure to ask your doctor about more serious treatments (such as steroids) that could stop diarrhea without causing side effects.
When Should I Call a Doctor or Health Care Provider About Diabetic Bowel Illness?
For some people, symptoms of diabetic bowel illness will go away on their own. If your diarrhea lasts longer than a few days, or if you have other problems such as stomach pain, call your doctor or health care provider. You may need to change your treatment plan. If symptoms are severe or continue for more than two weeks, get emergency medical help right away.
What Are the Long-Term Effects of Diabetes on the Bowel?
One of these long-term effects is to cause microscopic tears in the walls of your small intestine, which leads to inflammation. This, in turn, may lead to other problems, such as leaky gut syndrome and bacterial overgrowth. Inflammation and bacterial overgrowth also may increase your chances of having diarrhea. In some cases, inflammatory bowel disease may develop. Long-term diabetes can damage any part of your digestive tract.
How Do I Know If I Have Diabetes and Diabetes-Related Problems?
If you’re reading this, it’s likely you already know whether or not you have diabetes. However, if you’re still not sure and are hoping to figure out if there is anything wrong with your health, then simply ask yourself these three questions: Am I tired all of the time? Do I have to go to the bathroom all of the time? Do I drink more than 2 quarts of water per day? If you answered yes to two of those questions, then there is a very good chance that you are experiencing one (or both) signs of diabetes—diabetes-related problems are commonly referred to as the silent disease. It will be important for you to learn about diabetes; almost every American has either been diagnosed with type 2 or 3. Diabetes can cause many different complications (including erectile dysfunction), which can ultimately lead to death if left untreated; it would be wise for those suffering from any form of diabetic complication (like erectile dysfunction) to find professional medical help immediately!
Who Is at Risk for Having These Problems Related to Diabetes and Poor Blood Sugar Control?
People with diabetes can suffer from diarrhea and/or constipation, especially those who have just been diagnosed. Their blood sugar levels are likely not well-controlled, so they may not be eating enough fiber to help them stay regular. They’re also at risk for vitamin and mineral deficiencies that can cause problems (such as iron deficiency anemia). The following groups of people with diabetes are particularly vulnerable to diarrhea and/or constipation children and teenagers; pregnant women; elderly patients. Newer medications known as thiazolidinediones (pioglitazone or rosiglitazone) are commonly prescribed to help diabetics lose weight because these drugs increase insulin sensitivity and make it easier for your body to absorb nutrients.
However, recent reports indicate that some users experience severe diarrhea while taking these drugs in conjunction with medications called proton pump inhibitors, which inhibit stomach acid production in order to reduce gastrointestinal side effects from other types of medication (anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen). These side effects usually occur when taking a high dose of pioglitazone or rosiglitazone combined with any kind of gastrointestinal medication such as Nexium or Prilosec.

question: What are some of the possible reasons why there is an increase in the type 1 diabetes?
a_text:
Your query is a complex one… because to understand the cause of the rise in T1 (Type 1 diabetes mellitus), you must first understand what causes T1 - and to date, researchers have not quite figured that out; but we have a pretty good idea on the basics. So let’s start there.
T1 is an autoimmune disease, and is based in genetics. The exact genetics behind it are not fully understood - but there are several known genetic markers in the HLA complex that leave a person subject to the disease - but we also know that an environmental “trigger” is needed for the disease to manifest. Many folks carry the genetic anomalies for T1 - but never get it; this is why less than 20% of T1s have a T1 relative.
The known genetic markers are primarily located in the Human Leukocyte Antigen complex - or HLA complex. This section of the human genome is where our immune systems are formulated - and T1 is a failure of the immune system. There are some other markers in other locations that are known, but their role(s) is/are not understood fully - but they obviously have an impact on the development of the immune system.
The biochemical cause of T1 is an autoimmune attack on the tiny portion of the pancreas (about 2% of it in total) that makes insulin - the pancreatic endocrine beta cells, which make two hormones - insulin and amylin. We can live without amylin - but not without insulin. Until the isolation and purification of insulin from animal pancreases in 1921 by Banting, Best, Colip and MacLeod at the University of Toronto Children’s hospital, ALL T1s died within months of diagnosis. Since the vast majority of these patients were pre-pubescent children… none of them reproduced. So there’s ONE possible connection to the rise in the disease - for the past 90 years, T1s have been reproducing - meaning there’s more anomalous gene carriers than there were in the days when virtually all of them died before they were old enough to generate offspring. BUT… that’s not the likely answer. More on why in a moment.
Back to the biochemistry - the genetics cause a malfunction in the immune system, wherein the T-reg cells (the regulatory T cells, which are responsible for keeping the immune system from attacking it’s own body’s cells) fail to recognise “self”, and allow the killer T-cells to attack the insulin-producing beta cells. This brings us to the question of… why?
The short answer - so far; we don’t know this completely - is that some sort of “trigger” causes this to happen. We KNOW that certain viruses will trigger this malfunction - the enterovirus family is the most common trigger, plus mumps, rubella, rotavirus, and cytomegalovirus all of which are associated with the onset of T1. BUT… the subject must experience one of these viruses at a susceptible time. While many of these diseases have been severely limited nowadays, many are still quite common and even very mild (especially the enteroviruses), and patients may not even experience being “sick” with them - they’re short lived and very mild in their impact.
Based on this known requirement for an environmental trigger, several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the environmental side of the equation being the underlying cause of the increase. To start - the genetic side is unlikely; while there are now T1s that reproduce, thereby passing on the genetic markers - it hasn’t been long enough to explain the rapid rise in T1 incidence, and besides - the vast majority of carriers never did actually develop the disease - so the genetic markers are not likely much more prevalent than they were before T1s were surviving to reproductive age.
In the environmental cause camp - there are several competing arguments for why the environment is causing the increase in the rate of T1.
First, and most likely (so far) is the Hygiene Hypothesis (Strachan, 1989). Strachan showed that exposure to a variety of infectious agents is protective. Epidemiological studies (Gale, 2002; DIAMOND Project Group, 2006, Soltesz et al 2007) have shown that the rise in T1 incidence has been matched by a drop in infectious diseases such as tuberculosis, mumps, measles, hepatitis A, and enteroviruses. The mechanism of this process is quite complex, and way beyond this response… but if you’re interested in a more detailed analysis, read “In vivo Apoptosis of Diabetogenic T cells in NOD Mice”, in International Immunology, 2004, by Qin Hy, et al.
Next is the Viral Hypothesis. This theory proposes that the increase is somehow linked to the known viruses that “trigger” the disease - but since the introduction of vaccines to limit the incidence of these diseases has reduced the exposure to most of them, it doesn’t have a correlation to the rise in the incidence of T1. While the hypothesis is logical to the extent it is based on the known triggers, it just doesn’t fit as an explanation for the rise in T1.
Next is the Vitamin D Hypothesis. Vitamin D is known to play a role in the immune system function, via the VDR (Vitamin D Receptors) and enzymes involved in the immune system function. Finnish research has suggested an increase in the incidence of T1 following the reduction of Vitamin D supplementation (Hypponen et al, 2001). This one gets even more complicated - but it’s one of the hypotheses out there to explain the rise in T1.
There are several other hypotheses for the rise in T1… but one thing that is likely, is that it is NOT one single cause, but likely, a multi-factorial based occurrence. It simply seems unlikely that a single factor would drive it - especially with so many different factors involved in the aetiology of the disease in the first place.

question: What veggies are good for someone with type 1.5 diabetes?
a_text:
Q: “What veggies are good for someone with type 1.5 diabetes?”
Let’s start with “type 1.5 diabetes”… THERE IS NO SUCH THING. It is a MIS-reference to LADA DM - Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adult Diabetes Mellitus - or, simply, Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus. “Type 1.5” was a MISNOMER that came into use years ago as researchers were trying to categorise a type of DM that didn’t “fit” comfortably into the “traditional” versions called “Type 1” (T1) and “Type 2” (T2) DM. BUT… it is simply a late-developing (compared to Type 1) autoimmune disease - just like Type 1, and NOT Type 2 - though it’s later-onset (typically early 20’s as oppposed to childhood) causes it to be mis-diagnosed as T2… because unlike traditional T1, it does not IMMEDIATELY require insulin - though insulin is the BEST treatment method immediately from the start, in order to preserve beta cell function (pancreatic endocrine beta cells are the cells that produce insulin).
Unfortunately, the T1.5 terminology persists - even among docs, who are still not diagnosing patients until their BG (Blood Glucose) levels are WAY higher than normal (for example, a non-diabetic NEVER has a BG level above 150 mg/dl… but the diagnostic criteria maintain 200 mg/dl as necessary for a non-fasting BG in order to declare a patient “diabetic” - this is why some 70% of newly-diagnosed diabetics ALREADY HAVE some “complications” at time of diagnosis.
LADA T1 is usually treated the same as T2 by docs - because, in large part, there are so far no long-term studies of treatment methodologies for LADA T1. Unfortunately, this leads to complete loss of insulin-production before insulin treatment is started - and that’s a bad thing; LADA T1 should be treated the same way as T1s in the “honeymoon” period are treated - in order to maintain beta cell function.
As for dietary considerations - the point is NOT “what” you can eat… it’s HOW MUCH you can eat - of CARBS. CARBS, NOT “sugar”, are the issue in ALL types of DM. Because your body converts all carbs into glucose (the sugar our bodies run on) very fast. A slice of bread, or a teaspoon of table sugar - it’s all the same to your gluc-regulatory system. The bread will take an extra ten minutes to become sugar… but it does, and it’s fast enough to have little difference in impact. I’m not suggesting you replace proper foods with sugar - because foods contain various minerals and vitamins and fibre you won’t get from table sugar; but your BG levels are affected the same.
The POINT is to learn how many carbs to eat with each meal - and dose for them properly. “Veggies” is a generic term… and very inexact. AND… what a botanist calls a “veggie” is NOT what your gut calls a veggie. For example - corn is NOT a vegetable; it’s a carbohydrate. Yes, botanically, it’s a veggie… but that matters not a whit vis-a-vis your dietary management. Corn, potatoes, and so on are all loaded with carbs - so learning to count carbs, and limit EACH meal to the carbs your system can handle / your insulin dose is designed for, is the key to controlling BG levels.
Here’s some reading.
1 - LADA and its treatment: Recognizing and Appropriately Treating Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults
2 - Carb counting for beginners: https://www.bd.com/resource.aspx?IDX=9850
3 - Carbs by foods: http://www.med.umich.edu/1libr/MEND/CarbList.pdf
4 - Use your BG meter to manage diet: Test, Review, Adjust
5 - Diabetes education: Diabetes Education Online
Notes:
1 is a good intro to the diagnosis and treatment of LADA
2 is a good outline of how to count carbs and use the information.
3 is a simple listing of carbs by foods for guidance; when available, use the nutrtion label.
4 is a system geared to T2s that are NOT using insulin; you have to factor in your insulin use IF you are already using insulin - and that simply means you’ll have to learn how to use a CFR and ICR to calculate doses… see 5…
5 is an excellent resource for learning about management of diabetes mellitus of all types; as a LADA, the Type 1 section is the one you want to refer to, and the one I’ve linked you to; from there, there is a wealth of guidance and information.
Good luck!

question: Do preservatives cause diabetes type 2?
a_text:
Ultra-processed foods may raise the risk of type 2 diabetes
Sugary drinks, packaged snacks, and ready-made meals all count as ultra-processed foods — that is, foods that contain a higher number of additives and last longer because of the added preservatives. New research suggests that these foods also raise the risk of type 2 diabetes.
Research has linked ultra-processed foods with conditions such as cancer, obesity, and cardiovascular disease, as well as with a higher risk of premature mortality.
These foods are prevalent in Western diets, and the Western world has also seen a surge in the incidence of diabetes in recent decades. Are ultra-processed foods and type 2 diabetes linked? And if so, how?
Bernard Srour, Ph.D., of the Epidemiology and Statistics Research Center–University of Paris in France, and his team of researchers set out to answer this question.
They did so by examining the dietary habits of more than 100,000 people.
The results of their analysis appear in the journal JAMA Internal Medicine.
Ultra-processed foods and diabetes
Srour and team carried out a population-based prospective cohort study in which they included 104,707 adult participants who had participated in the French NutriNet-Santé study. Of these participants, 21,800 were men, and 82,907 were women.
The NutriNet-Santé study spanned a decade, running from 2009 to 2019. The researchers collected data on the dietary intake of the participants using repeated 24 hour dietary records that asked them about their consumption of about 3,500 different foods.
Using the NOVA classification system, the researchers classified the 3,500 food items according to their degree of processing. There were four categories: unprocessed/minimally processed foods, culinary ingredients, processed foods, and ultra-processed foods.
The researchers used multivariable Cox proportional hazard models, which they adjusted for the known risk factors for type 2 diabetes, such as sociodemographic background, lifestyle, and medical history.

question: How did people survive type 1 diabetes before the invention of insulin (history, medical science, people, life, medicine)?
a_text:
The simple answer is they didn’t. You cannot survive very long without insulin, so after it was diagnosed, generally the individual died within a few weeks or months if lucky.
BTW, insulin was not “invented.” Insulin is a natural hormone produced by islet cells in the pancreas. In Type 1 diabetes, those cells are destroyed by the immune system, hence it is an autoimmune disease.
In the 1920s, scientists were able to isolate insulin from the pancreas of pigs. Because insulin evolution has been very conservative porcine and bovine insulin were close enough to human insulin to allow doctors to regulate the blood sugar of type 1 diabetics. By the 1980s, we were able to genetically engineer real human insulin, which is what is used today.
Nevertheless, before the 1920s, if you were diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, you died. No one survived it.

question: What specific types of diabetes exist other than type 1, type 2, and gestational?
a_text:
Q: “What specific types of diabetes exist other than type 1, type 2, and gestational?”
There are SEVEN TOTALLY DIFFERENT DISEASES CALLED “DIABETES” - each with subtypes.
To start - there are two major groupings: Diabetes Mellitus - DM - (the ones you are talking about), and Diabetes Insipidus - DI. There are THREE types of DM, each with subtypes, and four types of DI, most with subtypes.
First, the terminology.
“Diabetes” is the term coined by Appollonius of Memphis (Greece) about 250 BCE; it literally means “siphon”, or “to pass through”, and is a reference to the constant urination in ALL the patients of these diseases - which Appollonius thought was a single disease.
The “second” names of these diseases were added by an English physician in the 1600s, to distinguish them from one another.
“Mellitus” is latin for “honey-sweet”, and is a reference to the glucose (sugar) in the urine of patients of those three diseases. All of which involve a lack of, or poor response to (or both) the hormone insulin, which results in a loss of gluco-regulatory control, leading to elevated BG (Blood Glucose - aka, sugar) levels.
“Insipidus” refers to the urine of patients of these four disease, which is colourless, odourless, and tasteless; or Insipid. These diseases all involve a lack of, poor storage of, or poor response to the hormone vasopressin. Vasopressin, aka “anti-diuretic hormone” controls fluid balance, inhibiting the kidneys from producing urine when fluid levels are proper or low; when our bodies need to clear out fluids, the hormone is withheld, and we urinate. In these patients, the hormone is either lacking or ineffective, and they must urinate constantly and excessively.
In DM patients, the excess urination is caused by BG (Blood Glucose) levels being too high; once they reach the renal threshold (about 180 mg/dl, or 10 mmol/L), the kidneys try to “flush out” the excess through the urinary tract, and that induces excessive urination - and resulting extreme thirst.
Back to the types of DM. There are three.
Type 1 is autoimmune DM, wherein a genetic anomaly leaves us susceptible to an immune system malfunction wherein the body’s own immune system attacks and destroys a tiny portion of the pancreas - the pancreatic endocrine beta cells (less than 2% of a healthy pancreas). These cells produce two hormones - insulin and amylin. Both of these serve to reduce BG levels when they rise; we can live without amylin - but NOT without insulin. This is why ALL T1s (Type 1 diabetics) must inject insulin to live. Insulin is essentially a transporter; it facilitates the transfer of glucose from the bloodstream (which is constantly carrying it around to cells that need it - and ALL cells need it in varying amounts and times) into the cells. If this transfer doesn’t happen - BG levels get too high, and the cells don’t get the fuel they need; without insulin, we die. Until the discovery, isolation and purification of insulin in 1921, ALL T1s died shortly after diagnosis.
Besides “traditional” T1, there is LADA T1. This is the same disease, but it develops more slowly, and after age 35. Traditional T1 can occur at any age - but about 80% of cases develop in childhood; the median age at diagnosis is 14. But LADA T1 develops after age 35, and more slowly.
There’s also a monogenic form of DM called Neonatal DM; this is technically not the same as T1, and many researchers consider it it’s own disease. But it’s usually “lumped in” with T1 because it ALWAYS happens in children - and often in unborn children. And always before 6 months of age. There are two sub-sub types of this one - “transient” and permanent. There are SEVERAL genetic markers that cause this, but all are single-gene anomalies; T1 involves multiple genetic anomalies. Like T1, NDM involves a lack of insulin - but NOT due to an autoimmune attack.
Type 2 DM (T2) is a disease wherein the body’s cells do not respond properly to insulin. This is called “insulin resistance”. These patients actually make MORE than normal amounts of insulin - but over time, the disease causes the cellular resistance to insulin to increase, and eventually - they can no longer make enough “extra” insulin to overcome that resistance, and BG levels rise too high. Gestational DM IS T2 - it’s a sub-type of it. During pregnancy, the placenta secretes hormones that cause increased cellular resistance to insulin, and others that clear insulin out; this results in elevated BG levels. The vast majority of women that experience GDM will ultimately develop T2 years later. SO… GDM is nothing more than “early onset” T2 due to the hormonal stresses of pregnancy. The genetics behind GDM are identical to T2. There are over 80 genetic markers associated with T2, but so far, only three that are absolutely confirmed as causative. Without the genetic markers, you don’t get the disease; but having them does NOT mean you must get the disease.
There are another 11 sub-types of T2 called MODY - Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young. M.O.D. is a left-over term from before we understood that the diseases are NOT related to age; but that naming convention still exists. Like NDM, these 11 disease are monogenic - and considered by many to be completely different diseases. But they involve cellular resistance to insulin (and a limited loss of insulin production), and have been associated with T2 for a long time. They are extremely rare, and most are very “mild” and rarely ever require insulin.
Finally, there’s Type 3c, or T3c. This is pancreatogenic DM, wherein an unrelated disease of the exocrine pancreas (such as pancreatitis, pancreatic cancer, haemochromatosis, or cystic fibrosis) damages the endocrine pancreas - including those endocrine beta cells, leaving the patient with severely reduced insulin production. Each of the diseases that cause this is a sub-type; so, for a pancreatic cancer patient, it’s Type 3c Pancreatic Cancer. And so on. These are all known as “secondary” DM, because they are secondary to the underlying disease.
SO… that’s an outline of the many diseases called “diabetes”. They are all different, have different causes, and significant differences in treatments.

question: Is Type 1 diabetes a chronic illness?
a_text: Type 1 diabetes, once known as juvenile diabetes or insulin-dependent diabetes, is a chronic condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin. Insulin is a hormone needed to allow sugar (glucose) to enter cells to produce energy. Diabetes is a chronic (long-lasting) health condition that affects how your body turns food into energy. Most of the food you eat is broken down into sugar (also called glucose) and released into your bloodstream.

question: Are type 1 and type 2 diabetes treated differently?
a_text:
Q: “Are type 1 and type 2 diabetes treated differently?”
Are a bullet wound and a compound leg fracture treated differently? After all, they both result in excessive bleeding.
Yes, T1 (Type 1 DM - Diabetes Mellitus) and T2 (Type 2 DM) are treated differently - because they are two TOTALLY DIFFERENT diseases; Type 3c, or T3c, is yet ANOTHER COMPLETELY DIFFERENT disease. Let’s review.
ALL three types of DM involve a malfunction in the gluco-regulatory system that maintains BG (Blood Glucose) in a tight range of about 90 to 120 mg/dl (5.00 to 6.67 mmol/L for non-U.S. readers).
T2 is the most common type of DM, representing over 90% of all DM patients. It is GENETIC in nature - caused by genetic anomalies that cause the victim’s body’s cells to resist the action of insulin. You don’t get this disease without the genetic markers, but over-consumption of carbohydrates, excess weight, and a sedentary lifestyle will accelerate its onset. Of course, those are also SYMPTOMS - because the genetics that make you susceptible to the disease, also make you susceptible to those conditions as well. The PRIMARY treatments for T2 are “diet” and “exercise”. These are ABSOLUTELY necessary - there is NO “medication” that will work effectively without also employing these tactics.
By “diet”, we mean carb limitation. T2 is a disease of cellular resistance to the action of insulin. which means it takes a LOT more insulin to “clear” glucose from the bloodstream. Carbs are the PRIMARY source of glucose in our diets - so limiting carbs, and replacing them with proteins and healthy fats, lowers the amount of glucose your system has to deal with in the first place.
“Exercise” refers to ANY PA - Physical Activity. PA increases your cellular response to insulin - put another way, regular PA increases your body’s cellular response to insulin. AND… that response remains long after the PA ends; if you get REGULAR daily (or at least 5 days out of 7) PA, you will MAINTAIN improved cellular sensitivity to insulin. Most folks know that PA will “burn off” BG - Blood Glucose - but the REAL BENEFIT of regular exercise is CONSTANT improved cellular response to insulin.
There are MANY T2 medications that are used to augment these tactics to bring BG into range… but NONE is effective without ALSO employing “diet” and “exercise”. Some of these meds stimulate greater production of insulin (these are called “insulin scretagogues”), some slow the absorption of carbs in the digestive tract, some suppress the body’s natural BG-raising function (metformin), and some “flush out” glucose from the urine into the urinary tract. ALL of these medications have “side effects” - and NONE of them do ANYTHING to help T1 diabetics.
T1 is the next most common type of DM, at less than 10% of all cases. This is autoimmune DM, wherein the patient’s own immune system attacks and destroys the insulin-producing cells of the pancreas - the endocrine beta cells. These are LESS than 2% of a healthy pancreas. And they’re the ONLY natural source of insulin in mammals. The ONLY treatment for this disease is injection of exogenous insulin - for the rest of your life. Based on calculate basal doses, Correction doses, and Carb coverage doses. Without insulin - we die. Period.
Finally, there’s T3c - which is less than 1% of all DM cases. This version of DM is imposed when an unrelated disease of the exocrine pancreas damages the endocrine pancreas - and the cells that produce insulin. It results in a condition similar to T1, in which the victim must use exogenous insulin to replace lost insulin production - but less than the typical T1 needs, because typically, not all insulin production is lost; but then, each case is different, and must be assessed individually.

question: What does the A1C measure for my child's type 1 diabetes?
a_text:
Q: “What does the A1C measure for my child’s type 1 diabetes?”
To start… it’s A1c, and the full term is HbA1c. Hb stands for haemoglobin, and A1c is s sub-type of haemoglobin that has partially bound to glucose molecules, and is termed “glycated” - because the chemical process through which that happens is called glycosylation, and in this case (non-enzymatic glycosylation), glycation. Hence the full term - glycated haemoglobin.
Docs over-simplify the answer, saying it’s an “average” of your BG (Blood Glucose) over the past three months - but it’s NOT. Here’s a longer explanation of the HbA1c test and it’s meaning; be patient - there’s a lot here, but it’s important to understand.
The HbA1c test has NOTHING TO DO WITH BLOOD GLUCOSE measurements - averages or otherwise. What the HbA1c test measures is the percentage of your haemoglobin that has "glycated", or bound chemically with glucose molecules (sugar). The more glucose there is in your bloodstream over time, the more of your haemoglobin will have bound to sugar. This last point is the underlying cause of the utter misconception that the HbA1c is some kind of "average" of BG levels, which it is NOT - no matter how many times that falsehood is repeated. HbA1c is a sub-type of haemoglobin that is undesirable in high levels because it causes the damage to organs and blood vessels that result in the "complications" of D - blindness, kidney failure, heart disease, and so on. Besides the 1c subtype of HbA, there are 1a and 1b subtypes - just for clarification.

Non-D's HbA1c levels range from about 3.5% to 5.5% of overall HbA. For every point above that top end, you increase your risk of those complications by about 30% (a). THAT is the point of the HbA1c measure. BUT... keep in mind, even non-D's suffer (much lower rates of) heart disease, kidney disease, blindness, and so on. So while keeping your HbA1c as close to "normal" as possible significantly reduces your risk of these diseases, it is not a guarantee that you'll not get one/some of them.

Back to the "average" BG concept... as noted above, the more sugar in your bloodstream, the more glycation, and the higher the resulting HbA1c level. BUT... there are many other factors that affect your HbA1c level as well. The formula used to "convert" HbA1c to EAG (ESTIMATED Average Glucose) is based on AVERAGES of MANY different individuals - no two of which have the same biochemistry, nor do any of theirs exactly "match" yours. Trying to compute either one from the other (EAG from HbA1c, or HbA1c from BG) is a fool's errand.

The POINT of the EAG reference was to give patients an idea of what their HbA1c measure meant, in terms they were used to dealing with - BG levels. BUT... again, it's based on averages which are derived from large population studies which ASSUMES certain underlying biochemical constants that simply aren't true for each and every individual. The point of the EAG reference is to put the individual patient's control (or lack thereof) into perspective.

The important comparison for an individual patient is to his/her past HbA1c levels - NOT to a mathematically derived "average". Over time, the individual patient with improving control will see a lowering in the HbA1c levels... while a patient experiencing control issues will see an increase. AND... the HbA1c # itself is reliable for predicting those complications.

Factors affecting your HbA1c level (besides blood glucose levels) include your erythrocyte (red blood cell) lifespan (everyone's varies), haemoglobin variants (there are many different kinds and they react differently to the glycation process), use of Vitamin C or Vitamin E can cause a "false low" HbA1c result, as can low doses of Aspirin - while high doses of Aspirin can result in a false high (b). All of this - and more - should be considered when interpreting the results of the HbA1c test.

The "conversion" of BG #'s to HbA1c #'s, and vice versa, are a mathematical formula applied to the known # to INFER a value for the unknown #. Again, this formula ASSUMES you have the exact same biochemistry as the "average" of all of the patients tested in establishing the formula:
(28.7 x A1c) - 46.7 = EAG

So, for an A1c of 5.5%:
(28.7 x 5.5) - 46.7 = EAG
(157.85) - 46.7 = EAG
111 = EAG

Or, for a BG reading of 90:
(28.7 x A1c) - 46.7 = 90
(28.7 x A1c) = 90+46.7
(28.7 x A1c) = 136.7
A1c = 136.7/28.7
A1c = 4.76

BUT... remember that all this math is just that - what's important is measuring the actual HbA1c, and the actual BG levels - the fact that they're related is important, but trying to "prove" the math is foolishness - because NO individual's biochemistry is precisely the same as the average of the several large groups used to develop the formula, and furthermore - not even the same today as it was yesterday. And in order to get a valid BG "average" to compare to your HbA1c test - you'd have to test your BG at least 10 times a day EVERY DAY for the entire 100 days preceding the HbA1c test. And even 10 tests a day might be too few.
Nowadays, with CGMs (Continuous Glucose Monitors), the preferred method of measuring success is TIR - Time In Range. In short, this is simply a measure of the percentage of time a patient spends within their target range. Here’s a useful article on TIR: New Recommendations for Time-in-Range Targets During Continuous Glucose Monitoring Presented Today at the ADA’s Scientific Sessions


w.

(b) - NIH - PMC 3401751

question: Do type 1 diabetics have high or low blood sugar?
a_text:
Q: “Do type 1 diabetics have high or low blood sugar?”
Yes. To start… your query demonstrates a lack of understanding of what you are asking… so let’s start with some basics.
“Blood sugar” refers to the sugar in the bloodstream of animals, which is the monosaccharide (“single sugar”) glucose. We can get glucose from ALL the foods we eat… depending on various circumstances, we primarily get it from carbohydrates, but if we eat no carbs - our digestive tracts will generate it from the proteins and fats we eat (which are the only two other macronutrients in our diets).
Glucose is the fuel our bodies run on - literally; without it, we die (very fast). Too much, and we die (very slowly). It’s in our bloodstream for one reason - to be delivered to each and every cell of our bodies, which need it to live. The ONLY other fuel our bodies can use directly in lieu of glucose is ketones… which are derived from adipose (fat) and muscle tissue; this is what people that are starving, and folks utilising the “keto diet” are running on. Each cell of your body uses that fuel to perform a function called cellular respiration - which has nothing to do with your breathing; it refers to the process by which cells generate the energy they need to live.
In any event, in ALL living animals, BG levels rise and fall all the time, constantly, and sometimes changing very fast. Sometimes it’s “high”, sometimes it’s “low” - but it’s ALWAYS changing. AND… it’s always different throughout your body. After a meal, the highest concentration of glucose is in the vasculature of your small intestines; at the end of a long fast, the highest concentration of glucose will be in the vasculature of the liver - which supplies us with the glucose we need when there is no food present. The liver stores glucose (in a form called glycogen) for this purpose.
In adult humans, BG (Blood Glucose) ranges from about 90 to 120 mg/dl… or 5.00 to 6.67 mmol/L (outside the U.S., mmol/L is the standard measure of BG concentration). In children, the range is broader, ranging both higher and lower - but mostly higher, primarily due to growth and hormonal development.
“Diabetes” literally means “siphon” in ancient Greek… and refers to the primary symptoms of the SEVEN totally DIFFERENT diseases “lumped” under this term. Those symptoms are polyurea (excessive urination) and polydipsia (extreme unquenchable thirst”.
There are TWO major categories of “diabetes”: DI (Diabetes Insipidus), and DM (Diabetes Mellitus).
DI is a group of four relatively rare diseases involving a lack of, poor storage of, or poor response to the hormone AVP - Arginine Vasopressin. AVP is the fluid-balance hormone; it maintains your body’s fluid levels by regulating the excretion of urine from the kidneys. When AVP is lacking or ineffective, you can’t stop urinating; that dehydrates you. All of that results in the symptoms of polyurea and polydipsia. BG is NOT affected at all by these four diseases.
DM is a group of three diseases, each with multiple sub-types, which affect BG levels. All of these diseases involve a lack of, or poor response to, the hormone insulin. There are three “types”.
In all three types, the symptoms of polyurea and polydipsia are caused by BG rising too high - 180 mg/dl (10 mmol/L) or more. When BG is that high (or higher), the kidneys can no longer recover the glucose from the blood as they screen it; so instead of recovering it and storing it, they “spill” the glucose into the urinary tract/bladder. That requires fluid - to create urine; that dehydrates you, making you more thirsty; and forces you to urinate more.
Type 1 DM is Autoimmune DM; this disease is caused by a genetic pre-disposition wherein the immune system malfunctions. In response to an environmental “trigger” (one of several viruses - but there are many more “suspects” not yet confirmed), the immune system “goes rogue” and attacks and destroys a TINY portion of the pancreas - the pancreatic endocrine beta cells; these constitute less than 2% of a healthy pancreas. SO… in us T1s (Type 1 DM patients), about 98% of our pancreas is fine and fully functional. BUT… we produce NO insulin or amylin (a “helper hormone” to insulin, also produced in those beta cells).
Without insulin - we die. In a matter of a few weeks. Insulin is the primary hormone for transferring glucose OUT of the bloodstream, and into the cells of the body. Not all cells need insulin to achieve that transfer... but most do. So without insulin, most of the body’s cells starve to death. Even though BG levels rise much too high - because the glucose can’t “get out” of the bloodstream.
Insulin performs MANY other functions - but that’s the primary one causing problems in untreated T1 - type 1 DM.
SO… the standard treatment - and the ONLY treatment that works at this time - is to inject exogenous insulin to replace the natural insulin that is no longer there. We don’t have to inject amylin, because we can live without amylin; but we must inject insulin to stay alive.
BUT… miscalculate the dose by just a bit - and you can lower your BG levels too much, causing “a hypo” - a hypoglycaemic event, or “low”. Hypoglycaemia is “officially” from 70 mg/dl (3.9 mmol/L) and lower. But many folks will feel symptoms at slightly higher levels (feel faint, shaky, weak, irritable, et al).
Insulin is administered for two purposes.
First is basal needs. Insulin is needed to provide the fuel for heartbeat, breathing, brain function, digestion, and all the other autonomic functions your body does without you really thinking about it. This is achieved in us T1s with a fixed daily dose used every day - or infused by a pump at a constant rate all day long.
Second is bolus needs… which include two components of their own: mealtime glucose surges (when we eat, our digestive systems convert the food into glucose within about 1 to 2 hours), and “corrections” when BG rises too high. So before each and every meal… a T1 must calculate a dose of insulin to “cover” the glucose from the meal, and to “correct” BG IF it is too high. Those on MDI (Multiple Daily Injections) simply inject the insulin; a pump user simply schedules a “surge” of insulin infusion in addition to the ongoing basal “drip”.
SO… while the underlying problem in Type 1 DM is high BG levels… we experience both highs and lows once we’re being treated for it. Just like Normals (non-diabetics) do. BUT… our highs and lows are much higher and lower than Normals experience - if we’re not careful! ;-)

question: Is it true that COVID-19 can infect cells in the pancreas that make insulin?

As of last November, it was reported plausible but not certain that the virus could infect the pancreas and might be the cause of acute pancreatitis seen in some Covid patients.[1][2][3] The pancreas and some other internal organs share the receptor that SARS-CoV-2 uses to invade cells, and viral invasion of pancreatic cells has been demonstrated in cell cultures.[4]

question: My daughter developed type 1 diabetes late in life. Do her children run the risk of becoming a diabetic as well?
a_text:
Q: “My daughter developed type 1 diabetes late in life. Do her children run the risk of becoming a diabetic as well?”
To start… there are three basic types of DM (Diabetes Mellitus); one has NOTHING to do with genetics; one is genetic; and one is hereditary.
The most common type, T2 (Type 2 DM), accounts for OVER 90% of all DM patients, and is hereditary; that means that it is not only carried in the genetic code (primarily on chromosome 2 of the human genome - but also in some other places), but it also tends to manifest in successive generations. These folks are most likely to pass the genetic cause on to their children. This version of the disease is due to cellular resistance to insulin - and therefore requires dietary restrictions and regular exercise.
The second most common type, T1, autoimmune DM wherein insulin production is completely lost, accounts for less than 10% of all DM patients, and though it is genetic - it is NOT hereditary… but the genes that cause it are more likely than not to be passed on. BUT… it takes MORE than just the genetics to develop the disease. This disease requires insulin injections - and dietary controls geared to the amount of insulin used.
The third type, T3c, or pancreatogenic DM, has NOTHING to do with genetics (and accounts for less than 1% of all DM cases); it is a sort of collateral-damage version of the disease, wherein an unrelated disease of the exocrine pancreas (pancreatitis, pancreatic cancer, cystic fibrosis) damages the endocrine pancreas, and impairs insulin production, requiring dietary controls and insulin injections.
Back on T1… if your daughter was 25 or older when she gave birth, the child has a 1% chance of developing T1; if she was under 25 when she gave birth, the child has about a 4% chance. In the general population, the “odds” of developing T1 are about 0.02% (that’s me - aren’t I lucky? - the only “lottery” I’ve ever won).
KEEP IN MIND… these are just statistical “likelihoods”; there’s no certainty in them. you (and your daughter, son in law, and grandkids) could go nuts if you focus on this too much. question: Why do diabetics have to constantly measure their blood sugar?
a_text:
Q: “Why do diabetics have to constantly measure their blood sugar?”
DM (Diabetes Mellitus) refers to THREE totally different diseases that cause BG (Blood Glucose) levels to get too high - and when BG levels are too high, you die an early, painful, ugly death. Elevated BG levels cause elevated AGES (Advanced Glycation End productS) levels; these AGES adhere to and smother ALL the body’s tissues, and the glucose itself abraids the interior walls of the vasculature (blood vessels). The resulting damage causes hypertension, CAD, PAD, heart disease, strokes, blindness, and renal failure - and that’s just a few of the more ugly “complications” of DM.
BG is raised by ALL the foods we eat, but primarily, carbohydrates (fats and proteins also raise BG, but by much smaller amounts). BG is “burned off” by simply being alive - every cell of the body “burns” glucose as its fuel; but by exercising, we burn it off at a much greater rate - AND, most importantly (for Type 2 diabetics), exercise improves cellular response to insulin; Type 2 is CAUSED by cellular resistance to the action of insulin.
Insulin is ONE of SIX hormones that control BG levels. In non-diabetics, BG ranges from about 90 to 120 mg/dl (5.00 to 6.67 mmol/L for non-U.S. readers). There will be some brief excursions up into the 140’s mg/dl, or down into the 80’s mg/dl. But that’s a “tight” range, and staying within it is the key to forestalling the “complications” of DM. BUT… that’s very hard to do.
Type 2 (Insulin Resistant) DM is the most common type (representing more than 90% of all DM patients). It is CAUSED by genetics, which cause the biochemical “fault” of cellular resistance to the action of insulin - which is the hormone that allows glucose to transfer out of the bloodstream (the body’s “delivery system”) and into the cells - which NEED it for fuel. When the cells resist that transfer - too much glucose gets “left behind” in the bloodstream, and too little gets into the cells. This causes the brain to trigger the release of insulin’s primary counter-regulatory hormone, glucagon - which RAISES BG even more. For these patients, checking BG regularly to learn how much different types and amounts of foods raise their BG is the KEY tactic to adjust their BG levels. There are NO oral T2 (Type 2 DM) medications that will achieve this without also employing “diet and exercise” (carb limitation and REGULAR physical activity) to keep BG in range. Here’s a useful pair of pages on this for T2s:
For the newly diagnosed: Getting Started
Use your BG meter to manage BG: Test, Review, Adjust
Type 1 (Autoimmune) DM is the second most common type (representing less than 10% of all DM patients). It is CAUSED by an autoimmune attack on the pancreatic endocrine beta cells - the cells of the pancreas that make and release insulin. Without insulin, we die. Period. ALL T1s died prior to the discovery, isolation and purification of insulin in 1921. To know how much insulin to use, we must test our BG MANY times a day; I test mine about 8 to 10 times a day - upon waking, before each meal, one and two hours after each meal, and at bedtime; that’s usually 10 times because “upon waking” and “before breakfast” are the same test; but I skip some of those tests on different days.
Insulin is dosed in two components - “basal” and “bolus”. Basal insulin is a long-acting (24-hour) dose that provides the insulin needed to maintain basal metabolic functions - breathing, heartbeat, digestion, brain function, sight, and so on. This is generally a “fixed” dose that’s the same every day - though it can be adjusted from time to time to provide for “alterations” - having a cold or flu, travelling and experiencing higher stress levels, and so on, can affect the basal need. That requires paying attention to one’s response to changes in the environmental factors - and that requires regular testing.
Bolus insulin refers to the insulin needed to manage the glucose from food eaten. A rapid-acting insulin is used immediately before meals, based on the carbs to be eaten in the meal. An I:C ratio is used for this: an Insulin to Carb ratio. Mine is 1:8 - meaning I take 1 unit of insulin for every 8 grams of carbs I’m about to eat. SO… if my meal contains 40 grams of carbs, I’ll take 5 units of insulin (40/8 = 5). BUT WAIT… these mealtime doses ALSO include an adjustment dose. My pre-meal “target” BG level is NO MORE than 100 mg/dl. SO… if my BG before a meal is over 100, I add some insulin to the mealtime dose. Let’s say it’s 130 mg/dl before that meal. My CFR (Correction Factor Ratio) is 1:15 - meaning I take 1 unit of insulin for every 15 points above 100 mg/dl. At 130, that’s 30 points too high - 30/15 = 2, so I add 2 units to the 5 I’m taking for the meal itself, and my dose is a total of 7 units.
At two hours after a meal, my BG is supposed to be back to 100 mg/dl… if it’s not, I may take additional insulin to correct it (using the CFR, but also factoring in my IOB - Insulin On Board, which refers to the fact that the mealtime dose of bolus insulin is still working. The point of an additional correction is to address the possibility that I ate a greater quantity of carbs, plus some other possible causes of a greater post-meal spike.
In short - ANYONE using insulin (many T2s ALSO use insulin) must test frequently to get their insulin doses “right” - and keep their BG in range.
Type 3c DM patients are rare - less than 1% of all DM patients. Like T1s, they’ve also lost insulin production - but NOT due to an autoimmune failure. T3c, or pancreatogenic DM is caused by an unrelated disease of the exocrine pancreas that damages the endocrine pancreas, and impairs insulin production. These folks usually retain SOME amount of insulin production - but not enough. They too must use insulin, as T1s do.
SO… testing BG levels frequently is the key to staying alive - AND avoiding/forestalling the complications of DM. And BTW - MOST diabetics do NOT die of diabetes itself; they die of the “complications” - stroke, heart disease, kidney failure, and many others. ONLY by keeping BG as close to non-diabetic range can we live without those “complications”. I’ve been a T1 for over 53 years - and so far, have NO serious “complications”. I do suffer from mild hypertension - but it’s controlled. Just like my BG levels.

question: Which psychiatric drugs can cause diabetes type 2?
a_text:
Diabetes and the Psychiatric Patient
Diabetes mellitus (DM) is more prevalent among patients with psychiatric illness compared with the general population. In addition to this, psychiatric patients are at greater risk for developing metabolic syndrome (MetS).1 MetS is characterized by abdominal or central obesity, atherogenic dyslipidemia (i.e., elevated triglycerides [TG] and reduced HDL cholesterol), insulin resistance (IR), and hypertension (HTN).2 For these reasons, together with the potential for metabolic adverse effects (AEs) associated with numerous psychotropic drugs--most notably atypical antipsychotics (AAs)--psychiatric patients must be closely monitored. Pharmacists have a unique role in the monitoring process because of their knowledge about medications and their visibility in the health care setting.
Association of Psychiatric Illness With DM and CVD
Depression, anxiety disorders, dementia, schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder (BD) occur more commonly in DM patients. DM may be involved in the development of the first three conditions.3 The exact mechanism by which DM may be linked to these conditions is not fully understood.
There appears to be a bidirectional relationship between DM and depression.4 About 7% of DM cases are thought to be attributed to depression.5 Depression is associated with a 60% to 65% increased risk of DM.5,6 Depression, which is postulated to be a state of chronic stress, has been associated with elevated cortisol levels and hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis abnormalities.7-10 Additionally, depression has been associated with IR.9,11 Both depression and high cortisol levels are associated with an increased risk of MetS.12 A possible correlation has been found between a 10-point difference in Beck Depression Inventory score and a 1% (approximate) change in hemoglobin A1C (HbA1C).13 Depression also is associated with increased severity of diabetic complications.14
Central serotonergic function has been linked to both depressive symptomatology and IR.9 Further, depressed patients are more likely to be unengaged in self-care, noncompliant with dietary and weight-loss recommendations, or physically inactive--all of which can worsen obesity and IR.10,15 This risk is compounded by medications used to treat depression, which may contribute to weight gain (WG) and obesity and may be associated with increased risk of DM.4,10,15 Anxiety has been associated with an increase in inflammatory markers in DM patients, and up to 80% of DM patients experience anxiety secondary to their underlying endocrine abnormality.

question: Are diabetes treatments available around the world?
a_text:
Diabetes and insulin access worldwide
Diabetes, both type 1 and type 2, is a health condition that has to be managed all over the globe. The rates of diabetes, as well as the treatment of it, vary from country to country. As it is Diabetes Awareness Month, we wanted to take the opportunity to look at the current state of diabetes and insulin access worldwide, and how this could change in the future.
Some quick-fire figures
It is hard to accurately estimate the worldwide prevalence of diabetes, as many cases are undiagnosed. For this reason, estimates from different sources can vary.
Insulin access
People with type 1 diabetes rely upon insulin injections (or pumps) to control their blood glucose levels throughout the day, in order to prevent hyperglycaemia.
There are numerous treatments for type 2 diabetes, which used to be referred to as non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM). People that have been newly diagnosed with type 2 diabetes are usually prescribed metformin, a drug which improves insulin sensitivity and reduces the liver’s output of glucose. People with type 2 diabetes who do not achieve good blood sugar control with lifestyle and / or drug interventions may later be prescribed insulin to lower their blood glucose levels.
The cost of diabetes
Sadly, according to the World Health Organization (WHO), 1.6 million deaths are directly attributed to diabetes each year.
On top of this, the complications of uncontrolled diabetes can cause significant discomfort and can reduce quality of life. Complications include neuropathy (nerve damage), nephropathy (kidney damage) and retinopathy (eye damage).
What is the future?
There are some concerning stats regarding the state of diabetes worldwide, but it is not all doom and gloom.
Developments such as the rise of low carb and technology such as the Freestyle Libre and artificial pancreas show that progress is being made in bettering people’s diabetes control. People with type 2 diabetes are now able to put the condition into remissio, and this is significant, particularly as healthcare professionals had once assumed type 2 was a chronic, progressive disease.
